usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

component.name: Amazon CloudWatch Event
component.desc: Amazon CloudWatch Event.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Capture CloudWatch API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Record every call to Amazon CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs APIswhether it comes from the console, an SDK, or another AWS serviceby creating a multi-Region CloudTrail trail and delivering the events to a dedicated, protected Amazon S3 bucket. This preserves a tamper-evident audit log that security teams can query and retain long-term.

Implementation guidance

  1. Create or update the trail
    • In the CloudTrail console (or IaC), create a new organization or account trail and enable across all Regions so region-scoped CloudWatch actions are captured.
    • Log Management events Read + Write (these include every cloudwatch:* and logs:* API). No extra data-event selector is required.
  2. Deliver to a hardened S3 bucket
    • Choose or create a bucket in a log-archive account.
    • Block public access, disable ACLs, and add a bucket policy that:
    • {
       "Effect": "Deny",
       "Principal": "*",
       "Action": "s3:*",
       "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs/*", "arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs"],
       "Condition": {"Bool": {"aws:SecureTransport": "false"}}
      }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption and versioning; turn on log file validation to detect tampering.
  3. Retention and analysis
    • Set an S3 lifecycle rule to transition older logs to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive after your compliance retention window (e.g., 90 days Glacier, delete after 7 years).
    • Optionally stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon Athena table for real-time alerting and ad-hoc queries.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited to ensure the trail and bucket stay compliant.
    • Alert on StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or S3 policy changes via EventBridge SNS/ChatOps.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, verify that new Regions are still covered and that the KMS key policy allows only the logging account to encrypt/decrypt.
    • Re-run an integrity check with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during incident response exercises.

Implementing this control guarantees that every CloudWatch action is immutably logged and stored in a bucket that meets the principle of least privilege, supporting forensic analysis and regulatory retention.

references

  • Logging CloudWatch API and console operations with CloudTrail
  • CloudTrail security best practices

SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools

countermeasure.name: Continuously evaluate CloudWatch resources with Security Hub and AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Activate AWS Security Hub (AWS Foundational Security Best Practices or other relevant standards) and AWS Config to run compliance checks against every Amazon CloudWatch resourcelog groups, alarms, dashboards, Contributor Insights rules, and metric filterson a rolling basis:

  1. Turn on Security Hub in all Regions (or via AWS Organizations) and enable the standard that contains the CloudWatch controls (for example, CW_LOGS_1 Enable VPC Flow Logs alarms). Findings automatically surface when a log group, alarm, or metric filter violates the control.
  2. Enable AWS Config recording and deploy the Operational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatch conformance pack (or choose individual managed rules such as CLOUDWATCH_ALARM_ACTION_CHECK and CLOUDWATCH_LOG_GROUP_ENCRYPTED). These rules evaluate resource configuration at creation and on every drift event.
  3. Set up aggregation & alerting
    • Aggregate Security Hub findings to the delegated administrator account; forward high-severity CloudWatch findings to an SNS topic integrated with your ticketing/on-call system.
    • Use AWS Config aggregators or a central dashboard (Config History + Security Hub Insights) to view compliance trends across accounts and Regions.
  4. Automate remediation Attach EventBridge rules to specific finding types (e.g., missing encryption) that invoke an SSM Automation or Lambda function to apply the correct setting, then mark the finding RESOLVED.
  5. Governance & review
    • Include the conformance pack template and any custom Config rules in your IaC repository; fail CI/CD builds if they are removed.
    • Review rule parameters (log-group prefixes, alarm thresholds, required encryption keys, etc.) quarterly and update them as new CloudWatch features or compliance clauses appear.

By combining Security Hubs managed controls with AWS Configs rule engine, you gain continuous, standards-based assurance that CloudWatch is configured securely and remains compliant as your environment evolves.

references

  • Security Hub controls for CloudWatch
  • Operational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatch

countermeasure.name: Encrypt CloudWatch logs at rest with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Secure every Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group by associating it with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of relying on the default, AWS-owned key. A CMK lets you define your own rotation schedule, attach restrictive key policies, and audit every decrypt operation.

Implementation checklist

  1. Create or select a CMK
    • aws kms create-key --description "CloudWatch Logs CMK"
    • Enable automatic rotation (every 365 days) or schedule key rotation manually.
  2. Lock down the key policy
    • Add the CloudWatch Logs service principallogs.<region>.amazonaws.comwith encrypt/decrypt permissions.
    • Optionally restrict use to the specific log-group ARN with an kms:EncryptionContext:aws:logs:arn condition.
  3. Associate the CMK with each log group
    • New groups: aws logs create-log-group --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Existing groups: aws logs associate-kms-key --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Update IaC templates (CloudFormation/Terraform) so encryption is declared at build time and drift-detection fails when no key is set.
  4. Verify encryption
    • aws logs describe-log-groups --log-group-name-prefix /app/orders --query "logGroups[*].kmsKeyId" should return the CMK ARN.
    • Run a sample PutLogEvents; confirm CloudTrail shows Decrypt events that reference the CMK.
  5. Monitor and rotate
    • Enable CloudWatch alarms on kms:Disabled or kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion events for the CMK.
    • Rotate or retire keys via a controlled change window; re-associate log groups with the new CMK before disabling the old one.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Deploy the AWS Config rule cloudwatch-log-group-encrypted (or similar) and alert when a group lacks SSE-KMS.
    • Include a Security Hub/FSBP control to surface non-encrypted groups at the account level.

Following this procedure guarantees that all log data is encrypted with keys you control, meeting regulatory requirements for data confidentiality, key management, and separation of duties.

References

  • Encrypt log data in CloudWatch Logs using AWS Key Management Service
  • CloudWatch logs are not encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ and perfect forward secrecy for CloudWatch API communications
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudWatch endpoints already refuse TLS 1.0/1.1, but every client you manage must also negotiate TLS 1.2 or newer and present a cipher suite that offers perfect forward secrecy (PFS)for example, any suite that starts with ECDHE_ or DHE_. This prevents downgrade attacks and meets AWSs minimum-encryption requirement.

Implementation checklist

  1. Update runtimes and libraries
    • OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181+, .NET 4.6+, AWS CLI v2, and current AWS SDK releases all default to TLS 1.2.
    • In base images or AMIs, set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 (OpenSSL) or equivalent.
  2. Disable legacy protocols and weak suites
    • Web proxies or forwarders: ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3; ssl_prefer_server_ciphers off;.
    • Container or OS hardening scripts should strip TLSv1/TLSv1.1 and static-key suites (e.g., *_RSA_*).
  3. Add automated tests
    • CI step:
    • openssl s_client -connect monitoring.${AWS_REGION}.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 && \
       { echo " TLS 1.1 still accepted"; exit 1; } || echo " TLS 1.1 correctly rejected"
    • Repeat with -tls1_2; the handshake must succeed.
  4. Secure interface VPC endpoints
    • Allow only TCP 443 in the endpoints security group.
    • Inspect flow logs for any TLSv1/TLSv1.1 attempts and alert if they appear.
  5. Centralize enforcement
    • In AWS Organizations, attach an SCP that denies cloudwatch:* when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule or linter that fails images containing TLSv1/TLSv1.1.
  6. Continuous monitoring & patching
    • Run AWS Inspector or OS vulnerability scans monthly; rebuild AMIs/containers when OpenSSL or Java receives critical CVEs.
    • Review cipher-suite telemetry and rotate certificates if you retire old CAs.

Properly enforcing modern TLS with PFS ensures CloudWatch telemetry stays confidential and resistant to future key compromise.

References

  • Infrastructure security for CloudWatch
  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum protocol level for all AWS service API endpoints

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege CloudWatch access with IAM roles, permission boundaries, and key rotation
countermeasure.desc:
Provision every workload and human operator with only the CloudWatch actions it truly needs, delivered through temporary credentials, and ring-fence those permissions with a boundary policy:

  1. Design fine-grained policies
    • List the exact actions the principal needs (for example, logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, cloudwatch:PutMetricData).
    • Scope resources precisely (arn:aws:logs:eu-west-1:123456789012:log-group:/aws/lambda/orders:*) andwhere supportedadd aws:ResourceTag or logs:LogGroupName conditions to prevent horizontal sprawl.
  2. Use roles, not long-term IAM users
    • Attach policies to service roles (EC2 instance profiles, Lambda execution roles, ECS task roles) or to federated/SSO roles for humans.
    • Disable or avoid creating IAM users altogether; they require permanent access keys.
  3. Enforce permission boundaries
    • Create an account-wide managed policy that defines the absolute maximum CloudWatch scope (for example, deny wildcard logs:* or actions outside approved Regions).
    • Attach this policy as a permissions boundary to every role so even misconfigured inline or attached policies cannot exceed it.
  4. Rotate credentials automatically
    • Where access keys are still unavoidable (build agents, legacy scripts), store them in AWS Secrets Manager and rotate on a 90-day schedule with a Lambda function or the IAM credential-report alarm.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-unused-credentials-check and alert if a key is older than the defined window or unused for 45 days.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Run IAM Access Analyzer to surface unintended CloudWatch permissions.
    • Add a CI/CD linter that fails commits introducing logs:* or cloudwatch:* wildcard privileges.
    • Stream CloudTrail events to Security Hub and raise findings on PutUserPolicy, AttachRolePolicy, or CreateAccessKey that violate the guardrails.
  6. Review regularly
    • Quarterly, prune unused log groups and metrics, then tighten policies accordingly.
    • Re-evaluate the boundary policy as new CloudWatch features (e.g., Logs Insights, cross-account metrics) are adopted.

Implementing least-privilege policies, permission boundaries, and automatic key rotation ensures CloudWatch can collect the telemetry you need without giving principals the power to tamper with, exfiltrate, or overload log and metric data.

References

  • IAM policy examples for CloudWatch Logs
  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Mask sensitive data in CloudWatch Logs and keep credentials out of logs
countermeasure.desc:
Protect log integrity and privacy by enabling CloudWatch Logs data-protection masking on every log group and by ensuring that no secrets or personally identifiable information (PII) are written to log messages, metric dimensions, or resource tags.

Implementation steps

  1. Attach a data-protection policy to each log group (or at the account level).
    • In the console: Logs Log groups Actions Create data protection policy.
    • Choose relevant managed data identifiers (credit-card numbers, email addresses, access keys, etc.) or add custom regex patterns.
    • Select the De-identify (mask) action so matching substrings are automatically replaced with placeholders.
  2. Block credentials and PII at the source.
    • Review application logging code; exclude secrets, access tokens, or user data from log payloads.
    • Never place sensitive values in CloudWatch metric dimensions, loggroup names, or tag keys/valuesthese fields are not run through the masking engine.
  3. Test and validate before production.
    • Send sample events containing fake identifiers; confirm they appear masked in the console and when fetched with filter-log-events.
    • Enable the Audit action in the policy to emit CloudWatch metrics (DataProtectionFindings) and create alarms on unmasked detections.
  4. Automate enforcement with IaC and guardrails.
    • Store policy JSON in Terraform/CloudFormation modules; fail the pipeline if a new log group lacks the standard policy.
    • Add AWS Config custom rules that flag metric or tag values matching forbidden patterns (for example, AKIA[0-9A-Z]{16}).
  5. Review quarterly.
    • Update the list of data identifiers as regulations evolve (GDPR, PCI DSS, HIPAA).
    • Inspect DataProtectionFindings metrics and Security Hub findings; remediate services still emitting unmasked data.

Following this control keeps secrets and PII out of your observability pipeline, satisfies compliance requirements, and reduces the risk of accidental data exposure in logs.

References

  • Help protect sensitive log data with masking
  • Understanding data protection policies in CloudWatch Logs

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for all identities and grant least-privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
Strengthen account-level security by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on every human identityroot user, IAM users, and AWS IAM Identity Center (formerly AWS SSO) userswhile granting each identity only the permissions it needs (principle of least privilege).

Implementation guidance

  1. Root user
    • Enable a hardware- or FIDO2-compliant MFA device on the root account immediately after account creation.
    • Lock the root credentials away; use them only for break-glass tasks such as account-level billing changes.
  2. IAM users (if still required)
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies * actions unless the session is authenticated with MFA ("Condition":{"Bool":{"aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent":"true"}}).
    • Enforce a strong password policy (minimum 14 characters, symbols, rotation) and disable long-lived access keys where possible.
  3. Prefer AWS IAM Identity Center (SSO)
    • Create users and groups in AWS IAM Identity Center or a connected IdP (Azure AD, Okta, etc.) instead of IAM users.
    • Assign permission sets that map to IAM roles with narrowly scoped policies (read-only, app-admin, billing-view, etc.).
    • Require MFA at the IdP level; Identity Center passes the MFA context to the temporary session.
  4. Least-privilege permission design
    • Start with AWS-managed or service-specific job-function policies as a baseline, then remove actions not required.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer and last-accessed data to trim unused permissions regularly.
    • Apply service control policies (SCPs) in AWS Organizations to set account-wide guardrails (e.g., deny deleting CloudTrail, deny disabling MFA).
  5. Monitoring and enforcement
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as iam-user-mfa-enabled, root-account-mfa-enabled, and iam-password-policy.
    • Stream CloudTrail management events to an analytics platform; alert on DeleteVirtualMFADevice, DeactivateMFADevice, or policy changes that broaden permissions.
  6. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, audit all identities: verify MFA devices, rotate permission sets, and deactivate any unused IAM users.
    • Automate findings remediation with AWS Security Hub EventBridge Lambda to re-enable MFA or quarantine non-compliant users.

Following this control eliminates single-factor logins and minimizes blast radius by ensuring every human session is short-lived, strongly authenticated, and scoped to the minimum set of allowed actions.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user and IAM users
  • IAM security best practices

countermeasure.name: Restrict CloudWatch VPC endpoints using IAM resource policies
countermeasure.desc:
Create a custom IAM resource policy for every interface VPC endpoint that your workloads use to send metrics or logs to Amazon CloudWatch / CloudWatch Logs. The policy must:

  • Allow only the actions each workload needs typically logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, or cloudwatch:PutMetricData.
  • Restrict the callers network origin by adding either
    • aws:SourceVpc = vpc-xxxxxxxx (all traffic must come from the named VPC), or
    • aws:SourceVpce = vpce-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx (traffic must enter through the specific endpoint ID).

Example endpoint policy JSON

{
 "Version":"2012-10-17",
 "Statement":[
   {
     "Effect":"Allow",
     "Principal":"*",
     "Action":[
       "logs:PutLogEvents",
       "logs:CreateLogStream"
     ],
     "Resource":"*",
     "Condition":{
       "StringEquals":{
         "aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-0abc123def4567890"
       }
     }
   }
 ]
}

Attach a similar policy to each CloudWatch monitoring and logs endpoint; use aws:SourceVpc if the endpoint will be replaced regularly.

Implementation checklist

  1. Identify endpoints aws ec2 describe-vpc-endpoints --filters Name=service-name,Values=com.amazonaws.<region>.logs.
  2. Author the policy store the JSON in your IaC repo; parameterise the VPC or VPCE IDs.
  3. Attach the policy aws ec2 modify-vpc-endpoint-policy --vpc-endpoint-id vpce- --policy-document file://policy.json.
  4. Validate from another VPC/endpoint, attempt a disallowed action and confirm it fails with 403 AccessDenied.
  5. Monitor & rotate enable CloudTrail data events for CloudWatch Logs; alert if a denied action or a request from an unexpected VPC occurs. Review policies whenever new logging agents or VPCs are introduced.

Using least-privilege resource policies on the endpoint itself prevents rogue traffic from other VPCs or compromised routes from writing logs or metrics, even if the IAM identity has permissions.

References

  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints
  • Control access to VPC endpoints with endpoint policies

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for both Amazon CloudWatch (com.amazonaws.<region>.monitoring) and CloudWatch Logs (com.amazonaws.<region>.logs) so that all metrics and log-ingestion traffic stays on the AWS backbone and never traverses the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet & AZ planning Pick at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones; the endpoint puts an elastic network interface (ENI) in each one.
  2. Provision the endpoints
  3. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
     --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
     --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.monitoring \
     --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
     --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
     --security-group-ids sg-endpoints
    # Repeat for com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.logs
  4. Make sure Enable private DNS is turned on (default) so SDKs and agents resolve the service names to the endpoint ENIs automatically.
  5. Tighten the security group attached to the endpoint ENIsallow only TCP 443 from the CIDRs or security groups that host your producers (EC2, Lambda in VPC, containers).
  6. (Optional) attach an endpoint policy that limits actions such as cloudwatch:PutMetricData or logs:PutLogEvents and uses aws:SourceVpc/aws:SourceVpce conditions for extra defense-in-depth.
  7. Validate from a private instance:
    • dig monitoring.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com A should return a 10.x address (your ENI).
    • aws logs put-log-events should succeed without an Internet gateway or NAT.
  8. Governance Add an AWS Config rule (managed or custom) that checks every account/Region for the presence of the two endpoints and alarms if missing. Share endpoints across spoke VPCs with AWS RAM instead of duplicating them.
  9. Monitor CloudWatch publishes metrics like InterfaceEndpointActiveConnections; set alarms for connection errors or throttling to detect misconfiguration or abuse.

By routing monitoring data entirely inside your VPC, you close an unnecessary egress path, reduce latency, and align with compliance mandates that forbid public-internet traffic for observability pipelines.

References

  • Using CloudWatch with interface VPC endpoints
  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS CloudWatch occurs when attackers obtain valid AWS credentials (access keys, session tokens, or IAM user passwords) that allow them to read, modify, or delete monitoring data, dashboards, alarms, and logs.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Phishing or social engineering to harvest IAM user credentials.
    • Exploiting leaked keys in code repositories or configuration files.
    • Hijacking EC2 instance or Lambda role tokens via metadata API access.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized users can view sensitive log and metric data.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers can disable alarms, delete dashboards, or purge log groups.
  • Stealthy Persistence: Malicious actors hide their activities by modifying retention settings or suppressing notifications.
  • Compliance Violations: Tampering with audit trails and alerts can breach regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phished Access Key Abuse: An attacker tricks an engineer into revealing AWS keys, then calls CloudWatchs DeleteAlarms and DeleteDashboards APIs to blind the operations team.
  2. Leaked Config Leak: A CI/CD pipeline inadvertently exposes CloudWatch IAM keys in a public commit; attackers use them to export VPC Flow Logs and exfiltrate network traffic data.
  3. Instance Metadata Exploit: Malware on an EC2 instance reads its attached roles temporary credentials, then uses PutMetricData to inject falsified metrics and mask malicious activity.

threat.name: Excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Excessive IAM permissions occur when users, roles, or service accounts are granted more CloudWatch privileges than requiredoften via overly broad policies or wildcard actionsenabling unauthorized operations across monitoring, logging, and alerting functions.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and errant automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Assigning policies like cloudwatch:* or logs:* on * resources.
    • Wildcard principals ("Principal": "*") or overly permissive condition-less statements.
    • Service-linked roles with unchecked trust relationships.

Impacts

  • Data Tampering & Deletion: Attackers can delete log groups or metrics, erasing forensic evidence.
  • Alert Suppression: Overprivileged actors disable alarms or modify thresholds to hide incidents.
  • False Metrics Injection: Unauthorized use of PutMetricData can mask malicious activity or skew dashboards.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Unchecked changes to retention settings and alarms undermine audit trails and regulatory controls.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Log Erasure: A compromised automation role with logs:DeleteLogGroup permission removes critical application logs to cover tracks after a breach.
  2. Alarm Tampering: An insider granted cloudwatch:DisableAlarmActions silences highseverity alerts during an unauthorized infrastructure change, delaying detection.
  3. Metric Pollution: An attacker uses PutMetricData on production namespaces to inject misleading metrics, causing ops teams to chase false positives.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: No encryption in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch trafficsuch as agenttoCloudWatch logs, metric submissions, or crossregion stream replicationis sent without TLS, all data in flight is exposed to interception and manipulation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Network eavesdroppers, MITM attackers, malicious insiders
  • Vectors: Sniffing unencrypted HTTP calls from CloudWatch agents; intercepting nonTLS API requests; exploiting misconfigured SDKs that disable SSL

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive logs and metric payloads (PII, credentials) can be harvested
  • Data Tampering: Inflight modification of metrics or alarms skews monitoring and hides real issues
  • Compliance Breach: Transmitting regulated data unencrypted violates standards like PCIDSS or GDPR

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Agent Sniffing: An attacker on the same subnet captures unencrypted CloudWatch Logs HTTP requests, extracting application stack traces and secrets.
  2. MITM Metric Injection: A malicious gateway intercepts and alters CloudWatch metric submissions to suppress alerts about unauthorized activity.
  3. Replication Hijack: Crossregion log replication over plaintext is hijacked, diverting logs to an attackercontrolled endpoint for analysis.

threat.name: Public network exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Public network exposure occurs when CloudWatch endpoints (APIs, agent ports, or log ingestion interfaces) are reachable over the Internet without network restrictions, allowing any external actor to interact with your monitoring services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning for and calling the CloudWatch Logs or Metrics API from the public Internet.
    • Misconfigured security groups or VPC settings that leave agent ports (e.g., the CloudWatch Agents HTTP endpoint) open.
    • Exploiting default or missing endpoint access controls to push or pull data.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Ingestion: Attackers can inject falsified metrics or logs, corrupting dashboards and alerts.
  • Data Exfiltration: Public access to Logs APIs may let adversaries retrieve sensitive telemetry or application logs.
  • Cost Spikes: Malicious actors flood your CloudWatch with high-volume custom metrics or log entries, driving up usage fees.
  • Monitoring Disruption: Overloaded or tampered endpoints can degrade or disable your monitoring pipelines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Bogus Metric Flood: An attacker discovers your open CloudWatch PutMetricData endpoint and sends thousands of custom metrics per second, inflating costs and obscuring real alerts.
  2. Log Data Harvesting: Without VPC restrictions, a malicious user calls FilterLogEvents on critical log groups, extracting PII or credentials from application logs.
  3. Agent Endpoint Abuse: A misconfigured CloudWatch Agent on EC2 listens publicly; an attacker posts large log payloads to its HTTP listener, saturating instance CPU and network.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data exposure in CloudWatch occurs when logs, metrics, or dashboard widgets inadvertently contain PII, credentials, or proprietary information and are accessible to unauthorized parties due to misconfiguration or overly broad access.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain read access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Overly permissive CloudWatch Logs resource policies or IAM roles (logs:FilterLogEvents on *).
    • Debug or application logs that record sensitive fields (passwords, tokens, user data).
    • Uncontrolled export of logs to S3 buckets without proper bucket policies.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of customer PII, credentials, or proprietary business data.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCIDSS.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and potential legal liability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Logs Policy Overexposure: A wildcard IAM policy grants all users logs:GetLogEvents on critical log groups; an attacker enumerates and downloads entries containing API keys.
  2. Debug Logging Leak: A misconfigured application writes full credit-card numbers to CloudWatch Logs; any user with log-read permissions can harvest them.
  3. Unprotected S3 Export: Automated CloudWatch Logs export to an S3 bucket lacks encryption and publicaccess blocks, allowing anyone with the bucket URL to download sensitive audit trails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information

threat.name: Endpoint policy misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch endpoint policies are too permissive or misscoped, unintended principals or networks can access or modify Logs, Metrics, or Alarmseffectively bypassing intended security boundaries.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised AWS accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • VPC Endpoint policies using "Principal": "*", granting universal access
    • Missing aws:sourceVpce conditions, allowing unauthorized VPC or onprem queries
    • Crossaccount Logs policies (logs:GetLogEvents, logs:PutLogEvents) without proper scoping

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Reading sensitive log data
  • Data Tampering: Injecting or overwriting metrics/logs
  • Boundary Bypass: Internal traffic routed without firewall inspection

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Principal Abuse: An attacker in another account uses a wildcardprincipal VPC endpoint to flood your log groups with bogus entries, masking genuine alerts.
  2. CrossAccount Leak: A mis-scoped Logs policy lets an external AWS account pull your applications error logsincluding API keysfor reconnaissance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data at rest occurs when CloudWatch retains logs, metrics, or exported dashboards on disk or in S3 without encryption, leaving sensitive information exposed if storage is accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain storage access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Disabling or failing to configure CloudWatch Logsencryption keys (KMS).
    • Exporting logs to S3 buckets without SSE or bucketlevel encryption.
    • Stealing EBS snapshots or backup files containing unencrypted metrics data.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: PII, credentials, or proprietary information in logs can be read directly.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA, PCIDSS).
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust if audit trails reveal sensitive customer or internal data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Export Leak: An audit log export to an S3 bucket lacks SSEKMS; an attacker with S3 read access downloads and harvests sensitive entries.
  2. Snapshot Theft: A malicious insider copies unencrypted EBS snapshots backing CloudWatch metrics storage, then mounts them elsewhere to inspect raw data.
  3. KMS Misconfiguration: CloudWatch Logs are left using the default AWSmanaged key instead of a restricted CMK; after an account breach, an attacker decrypts archived logs to glean secrets.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch fails to record administrative or dataaccess eventssuch as IAM changes, alarm modifications, or logretrievalstheres no trail of who did what, making detection and investigation of malicious or accidental actions impossible.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and automated malware.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Performing API calls (e.g. DeleteLogGroup, DisableAlarmActions) without corresponding CloudTrail or CloudWatch Logs entries.
    • Exploiting gaps in retention or delivery settings that drop audit events.
    • Leveraging direct SDK or CLI calls that bypass configured logging hooks.

Impacts

  • Delayed Detection: Unauthorized changes go unnoticed, extending dwell time.
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cannot be reconstructed, hindering rootcause analysis.
  • Compliance Failures: Absence of required audit trails breaches standards like PCIDSS, HIPAA, or SOC2.
  • Persistent Threats: Attackers maintain covert access and alter settings without fear of discovery.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealthy Log Deletion: An attacker with delete rights removes critical log groups; without audit logs, theres no record of who or what triggered the deletion.
  2. Alarm Suppression: A malicious actor disables highseverity alarms via the API; absent audit entries, oncall teams remain unaware of the suppression and miss critical alerts.
  3. Configuration Tampering: A compromised automation script updates metric thresholds to hide malicious activity; without changelogs, the tampering is indistinguishable from legitimate updates.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Noncompliance monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Noncompliance monitoring occurs when CloudWatch isnt configured to track or alert on departures from security, operational, or regulatory policiesallowing violations (e.g., disabled encryption, open ports, expired certificates) to go undetected.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, and external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Failing to create CloudWatch Alarms for key compliance metrics (e.g., IAM policy changes, public S3 buckets).
    • Omitting EventBridge rules to capture CloudTrail noncompliant events.
    • Not using Config rules or custom metrics for regulatory controls.

Impacts

  • Undetected Violations: Security misconfigurations and policy breaches persist unnoticed.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Failure to monitor compliance can lead to fines under standards like PCIDSS, HIPAA, or GDPR.
  • Increased Attack Surface: Misconfigurations (e.g., exposed databases) remain open until manually discovered.
  • Reputational Damage: Extended noncompliance erodes customer and stakeholder trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unmonitored Public Bucket: An S3 bucket holding PII is made public; without a CloudWatch Alarm on the PublicAccess metric, the exposure isnt detected for days.
  2. Expired TLS Certificate: A load balancers certificate expires; no metric or alarm is set for certificate age, causing encrypted traffic to fail without alert.
  3. IAM Policy Drift: An administrator grants AdministratorAccess to a user; absent an EventBridge rule to flag policy changes, the overprivileged account is created without notification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

component.name: Amazon DynamoDB
component.desc: Amazon DynamoDB database.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isnt available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to configure and invoke EventBridge targets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge targets, apply IAM policies that restrict which users and roles have permissions to configure and invoke targets. These policies ensure that only authorized entities can trigger actions on the EventBridge targets, preventing unauthorized operations and maintaining the integrity of the event-driven workflow.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the specific actions (e.g., PutRule, PutTargets, InvokeFunction) that need to be restricted and identify the users and roles that require these permissions.
  2. Create IAM Policies: Develop IAM policies that explicitly define which users and roles are allowed to configure and invoke EventBridge targets. Use least privilege principles to grant only the necessary permissions required for their roles.
  3. Attach Policies to Users and Roles: Attach the IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles in AWS IAM to enforce the defined access restrictions.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review IAM policies to ensure they are up-to-date with current organizational requirements and remove any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Monitor Access and Usage: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor who is configuring and invoking EventBridge targets. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or actions.

reference.name: Using identity-based policies (IAM policies) for Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging for all event activities in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility and security monitoring in AWS EventBridge, enable detailed logging for all event activities. Use Amazon CloudWatch Logs and AWS CloudTrail to capture and monitor event-related actions, including event publishing, rule evaluation, and target invocation. Detailed logging helps detect unauthorized access, misconfigurations, and anomalies, allowing timely incident response and improving overall security posture.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable CloudTrail for EventBridge: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled for your AWS account to log all EventBridge API calls. Configure CloudTrail to log both management events and data events for comprehensive coverage.
  2. Set Up CloudWatch Logs: Create log groups and set up CloudWatch Logs to capture and store logs generated by EventBridge activities. Ensure logs are retained for an appropriate period based on your organization's retention policy.
  3. Monitor Logs and Set Alerts: Use CloudWatch metrics and alarms to monitor EventBridge activity logs for any unauthorized or suspicious actions. Configure alerts to notify security teams of any anomalies or potential security incidents.
  4. Regularly Review Logs: Schedule regular reviews of CloudWatch Logs and CloudTrail logs to identify trends, detect potential threats, and ensure compliance with security policies.
  5. Audit Log Configurations: Periodically audit logging configurations to ensure that all EventBridge activities are being logged correctly and that logging mechanisms are operating as intended.

reference.name: Logging Amazon EventBridge API calls using AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in event payloads before sending to AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To protect sensitive data transmitted through AWS EventBridge, ensure that all sensitive information included in event payloads is encrypted before being sent. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encrypting data to safeguard against unauthorized access and potential data breaches. Encrypting sensitive data ensures its confidentiality and integrity, even if it is intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data: Determine which data fields in event payloads contain sensitive information that requires encryption, such as personally identifiable information (PII) or financial details.
  2. Use AWS KMS for Encryption: Utilize AWS KMS to encrypt sensitive data within the payloads. Integrate AWS KMS encryption into your application's event generation process to automatically encrypt sensitive data before sending it to EventBridge.
  3. Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure that encrypted payloads are transmitted over secure channels, such as HTTPS, to add another layer of protection during data transit.
  4. Regularly Review Encryption Policies: Periodically review and update encryption practices and KMS key policies to align with organizational security standards and compliance requirements.
  5. Audit Encrypted Payloads: Regularly audit event payloads to verify that sensitive data is properly encrypted and that no plaintext sensitive information is sent through EventBridge.

reference.name: Data protection in Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and validate event rule configurations in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain secure and efficient event routing in AWS EventBridge, regularly review and validate the configuration of event rules. Ensure that each rule routes events only to authorized targets and that the configurations are not overly permissive. This practice adheres to the principle of least privilege, minimizing the risk of unauthorized actions or data exposure.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Schedule Regular Rule Reviews: Establish a routine schedule for reviewing all EventBridge event rules to ensure they are properly configured and align with security policies.
  2. Validate Target Authorizations: Check that each event rule routes events only to authorized targets, and ensure that no unauthorized targets are included.
  3. Minimize Rule Permissions: Review rule conditions and filters to ensure they are specific and not overly broad or permissive. Adjust configurations to follow the principle of least privilege.
  4. Document and Track Changes: Maintain a log of all rule reviews and any changes made to event rule configurations for auditing purposes.
  5. Automate Validation Checks: Where possible, automate the validation of event rule configurations using AWS Config or custom scripts to identify any non-compliant or overly permissive rules.

reference.name: Creating a rule that runs on a schedule in Amazon EventBridge

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to restrict access to the EventBridge event bus
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge event buses, implement resource-based policies that restrict access to only authorized AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users. By defining specific permissions within these policies, you can control who can publish or subscribe to events on the event bus, thereby preventing unauthorized access and ensuring that only trusted entities can interact with the event bus.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Authorized Entities: Determine which AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users require access to the event bus for publishing or subscribing to events.
  2. Create Resource-Based Policies: Develop resource-based policies that explicitly grant the necessary permissions (e.g., PutEvents, DescribeRule, ListTargets) to the identified entities. Specify conditions where appropriate to further refine access.
  3. Attach Policies to the Event Bus: Attach the resource-based policies directly to the event bus to enforce the defined access controls. Ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the resource-based policies to ensure they remain up-to-date with current access requirements and revoke any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Audit Access Logs: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor access to the event bus, ensuring compliance with the defined policies and detecting any unauthorized access attempts.

reference.name: Permissions for event buses in Amazon EventBridge
