weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-784
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-784: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie, but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies, within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Attackers can bypass protection mechanisms such as authorization and authentication by modifying the cookie to contain an expected value.

weakness.name: CWE-786
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-786: Access of Memory Location Before Start of Buffer The product reads or writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer. This typically occurs when a pointer or its index is decremented to a position before the buffer, when pointer arithmetic results in a position before the beginning of the valid memory location, or when a negative index is used.

countermeasure.name: Continuously monitor chatbot interactions and update training data to eliminate bias
countermeasure.desc:
Implement continuous monitoring of chatbot interactions to identify and address any potential biases in the responses. Regularly review the chatbot's training data and update it with diverse, representative data to ensure fair and unbiased interactions with users. This practice helps prevent the chatbot from reinforcing stereotypes or providing discriminatory responses, ensuring an inclusive and equitable user experience.

References:

  • OWASP Best Practices for Preventing AI Bias

standard.ref: Information security awareness, education and training
PR.AT-1: All users are informed and trained
PR.AT-2: Privileged users understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-3: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-4: Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-5: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities

countermeasure.name: Ensure data is transmitted over secure protocols like HTTPS
countermeasure.desc:
Implement HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure) for all data transmissions to ensure encryption during transit, preventing unauthorized interception and tampering of sensitive data. By enforcing the use of HTTPS, you protect chatbot communications and user data from man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks and other forms of eavesdropping. This ensures data integrity and confidentiality between users and the chatbot system.

References:

  • Secure Communication Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement end-to-end encryption for chatbot conversations
countermeasure.desc:
Implement end-to-end encryption (E2EE) for all chatbot conversations to ensure that user data is encrypted during transit and can only be decrypted by the intended recipient. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive information by protecting messages from being intercepted or read by attackers or third parties during transmission. Both the chatbot and the users device should perform encryption and decryption operations, ensuring complete confidentiality throughout the communication process.

References:

  • OWASP End-to-End Encryption Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Perform regular security evaluations of integrated services
countermeasure.desc:
Conduct regular security evaluations of all third-party services and APIs integrated with the chatbot. This includes assessing security configurations, checking for vulnerabilities, ensuring compliance with security best practices, and verifying that all integrated services are updated to the latest secure versions. Regular evaluations help identify and mitigate potential risks that could be exploited, ensuring that the overall security posture of the chatbot remains strong and resilient to attacks.

References:

  • OWASP API Security Top 10

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Require multi-factor authentication for accessing the chatbot
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) or other strong authentication methods before granting users access to the chatbot. This additional layer of security helps ensure that only authorized users can interact with the chatbot, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or impersonation. MFA can include a combination of something the user knows (password), something the user has (smartphone or hardware token), or something the user is (biometric authentication).

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Best Practices

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Set limits on API usage to prevent abuse and ensure fair usage
countermeasure.desc:
Implement rate limiting and usage quotas for API endpoints used by the chatbot to prevent abuse and ensure that resources are fairly distributed among all clients. By limiting the number of requests a user or system can make in a specific time period, you can mitigate the risk of denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, excessive load, or overconsumption of resources. Additionally, rate limiting helps maintain the chatbots availability and performance while protecting the backend services from being overwhelmed.

References:

  • OWASP API Security Top 10

standard.ref: ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Store data in secure locations with encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all sensitive data used by the chatbot, including user conversations and credentials, is stored in secure locations with encryption at rest. Encryption at rest ensures that data is protected when stored on disk or in databases, preventing unauthorized access in case of physical theft or unauthorized access attempts. Implement strong encryption methods and enforce strict access control policies to maintain data confidentiality and integrity.

References:

  • Encryption Standards

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: User data leakage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
User data leakage occurs when sensitive user information, such as personal details, conversation logs, or payment information, is inadvertently exposed to unauthorized parties. This can happen due to improper data handling, insufficient access controls, insecure storage, or vulnerabilities in the chatbots infrastructure, leading to a breach of user privacy and trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities in the system, such as insecure API endpoints, to access or exfiltrate user data.
  • Malicious Insiders: Gaining unauthorized access to sensitive user data through excessive privileges or misconfigurations in access controls.
  • Insecure Data Storage: Storing sensitive information, such as user credentials or conversation logs, in unencrypted or publicly accessible locations.

Impacts

  • Privacy Violations: Exposed user data can lead to identity theft, fraud, or unauthorized sharing of personal information.
  • Reputation Damage: A data leakage incident can severely damage the chatbot's credibility and the trust users place in the platform.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Failure to protect user data could lead to violations of data protection regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or CCPA, resulting in fines and legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A chatbot stores user conversation logs in an unencrypted database, and an attacker exploits a vulnerability to retrieve these logs, exposing sensitive user information.
  2. A malicious insider with access to the chatbots admin panel uses excessive privileges to extract personal details from the system, such as names, addresses, or payment information.
  3. A chatbot's API fails to enforce proper access controls, allowing an attacker to access user data sent during interactions, such as email addresses or personal preferences.

threat.name: Integration risks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Integration risks refer to the potential vulnerabilities introduced when a chatbot interacts with external systems, APIs, or services. Improperly configured or insecure integrations can allow attackers to exploit weaknesses in the connection between systems, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches, or the execution of malicious actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weaknesses in external systems or APIs that the chatbot integrates with, allowing access to sensitive data or functionality.
  • Malicious Insiders: Manipulating chatbot integrations to divert data, access unauthorized resources, or inject malicious content.
  • Poorly Secured APIs: Using third-party APIs or services that do not implement proper authentication, encryption, or access control mechanisms, creating a potential attack surface.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Access: Attackers or malicious actors can gain access to sensitive data exchanged between the chatbot and external systems, leading to data breaches.
  • System Compromise: Exploiting insecure integrations to gain unauthorized control over connected systems or services, potentially damaging the integrity of the entire platform.
  • Service Disruption: A successful attack on an integrated third-party service could cause the chatbot to malfunction, leading to service outages or degraded user experience.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an insecure API endpoint used by the chatbot to access and manipulate sensitive user data stored in an external database.
  2. A malicious insider tampers with the chatbot's integration with a payment processing service, redirecting funds to their own account.
  3. A chatbot integrates with an external weather service, and the attacker exploits a vulnerability in the service's API to inject malicious code into the chatbots response.

threat.name: Data storage vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data storage vulnerabilities occur when sensitive information, such as user data, conversation logs, or other personal details, is stored insecurely within the chatbot's system. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper encryption, inadequate access controls, or poorly secured storage configurations, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access to or tamper with stored data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weaknesses in the storage system, such as unsecured databases or storage buckets, to steal or modify sensitive data.
  • Malicious Insiders: Gaining unauthorized access to stored data using excessive privileges or bypassing access controls.
  • Misconfigurations: Storing sensitive data in plain text or using weak encryption methods, making it easier for attackers to access or decrypt.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to stored sensitive data, such as personal information or confidential conversations, leading to identity theft, fraud, or privacy violations.
  • Data Integrity Loss: Attackers altering stored data, which could affect the chatbot's functionality or trustworthiness.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to properly secure data storage could lead to violations of regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS, resulting in fines and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured cloud storage bucket containing sensitive chatbot logs and conversation histories, gaining access to private user data.
  2. A malicious insider uses elevated privileges to access and modify the chatbot's data storage, tampering with user conversations or personal details.
  3. A vulnerability in the database used by the chatbot allows an attacker to execute SQL injection attacks and retrieve sensitive user data stored in plain text.

threat.name: API abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
API abuse occurs when an attacker exploits exposed application programming interfaces (APIs) used by a chatbot to send malicious or excessive requests. This can result in unauthorized access, data theft, service degradation, or manipulation of chatbot responses. Without proper security controls, APIs can be misused for a variety of malicious activities such as flooding the system with requests or abusing API rate limits.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weak or poorly protected APIs to inject malicious inputs or perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.
  • Malicious Insiders: Abusing access to API endpoints or tokens to manipulate chatbot behaviors or extract sensitive data.
  • Automated Tools: Using botnets or scripts to flood the API with excessive requests, overloading the system.

Impacts

  • Data Theft or Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive user information passed through the chatbot's API.
  • Service Disruption: Overloading the chatbot's API with excessive requests, potentially resulting in downtime or degraded performance.
  • Unauthorized Actions: Manipulation of chatbot functionality, such as delivering malicious responses or altering user interactions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker discovers an unprotected API endpoint used by the chatbot and sends crafted input to steal user data.
  2. A malicious user scripts a DoS attack, sending massive amounts of API requests, making the chatbot unresponsive to legitimate users.
  3. An insider with API access exploits the chatbots API to modify conversation logs or redirect responses to malicious content.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Bias in chatbot responses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Bias in chatbot responses refers to the unintentional or systematic skewing of the chatbots replies based on biased training data or improper configuration. This can lead to discriminatory, unfair, or harmful responses that affect user experience, trust, and compliance with ethical standards. Bias in chatbot behavior can arise from biased datasets, poor design, or lack of diversity in training materials.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Manipulating input data or training materials to influence the chatbots responses in biased or harmful ways.
  • Internal Misconfigurations: Developers inadvertently training the chatbot on biased datasets, leading to skewed responses.
  • Data Poisoning: Attackers intentionally feeding the chatbot maliciously biased data to exploit or cause harm in specific use cases.

Impacts

  • User Trust Erosion: Users may lose confidence in the chatbots reliability and fairness, impacting brand reputation.
  • Legal and Ethical Violations: Biased responses could lead to legal challenges, particularly in sensitive areas like hiring, finance, or healthcare.
  • Discriminatory Behavior: Harmful biases could lead to discrimination or marginalization of certain user groups, negatively impacting inclusivity and user satisfaction.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A chatbot trained primarily on biased historical data provides discriminatory hiring recommendations based on gender or race.
  2. An attacker poisons the chatbots training dataset with harmful input to alter the chatbots responses towards a particular political ideology or controversial topic.
  3. A healthcare chatbot provides skewed medical advice based on biased training data, leading to incorrect or unsafe recommendations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate user authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Inadequate user authentication occurs when the process used to verify a users identity is weak, improperly implemented, or easily bypassed. This can include relying on weak passwords, failing to implement multi-factor authentication (MFA), or using insecure authentication methods. Inadequate authentication increases the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive user data or application features.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Using techniques such as brute force attacks, credential stuffing, or exploiting weak password policies to gain unauthorized access to user accounts.
  • Malicious Insiders: Exploiting weak or poorly implemented authentication controls to escalate privileges or access sensitive data.
  • Automated Tools: Attackers leveraging botnets or automated scripts to exploit vulnerabilities in authentication systems, bypassing weak controls.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain unauthorized access to user accounts or services, leading to data breaches, financial loss, or abuse of services.
  • Data Theft: Sensitive personal data or business-critical information may be exposed to unauthorized users.
  • Reputation Damage: Weak authentication systems undermine user trust and can harm the organizations reputation, especially in the case of a breach.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a brute-force attack on a weak password policy to gain access to user accounts and steal sensitive data.
  2. A malicious user exploits a vulnerability in the authentication process, bypassing MFA controls and gaining unauthorized access to a users profile.
  3. A chatbot fails to verify user credentials securely and allows an attacker to impersonate a legitimate user by guessing simple passwords or using stolen credentials.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-477
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-477: Use of Obsolete Function The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Associate custom NACLs to subnets with strict rule sets
countermeasure.desc:
Replace the default, permissive network ACL with a custom NACL for each subnet and populate it with explicit allow rules for only the ports, protocols, and CIDRs your workload actually needs. Everything else is implicitly denied.

Implementation steps

  1. Create a dedicated NACL per subnet rather than sharing one across the VPC. This limits blast radius and simplifies audits.
  2. Build the rule set top-down
    • Low rule numbers (100, 110) for required inbound portse.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR, or TCP 5432 from the app subnet.
    • Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound allow for the ephemeral port range (1024-65535) so return traffic succeeds.
    • End with rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress to block any traffic you forgot to list.
  3. Avoid state exposure by blocking dangerous protocols and port ranges you never use (UDP 0-1023, TCP 23, 3389, etc.).
  4. Automate association in CloudFormation/Terraform:
    1. SubnetNACLAssociation:
       Type: AWS::EC2::SubnetNetworkAclAssociation
       Properties:
         SubnetId: !Ref PrivateSubnetA
         NetworkAclId: !Ref PrivateNACL
  5. Validate & monitor
    • Turn on VPC Flow Logs for the subnet; alarm on REJECT counts or unexpected source IPs.
    • Use Reachability Analyzer after every deployment to confirm intended paths still work.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags subnets using the default NACL or any NACL without a DENY-ALL rule.
    • Review rule sets quarterly; remove obsolete ports and tighten CIDRs.

Strict, subnet-specific NACLs provide a stateless firewall layer that backs up your security-group strategy and blocks accidental or malicious traffic at the VPC edge.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs and AWS config rules for NACL changes
countermeasure.desc:
Add continuous, two-layer visibility to every network ACL (NACL) so you can see what traffic is blocked or allowed and who modified the rule set:

  1. Stream data-plane traffic with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (format version 3) on every subnet that the NACL protects as well as on its individual ENIs.
    • Deliver logs to CloudWatch Logs (90-day retention) or S3 + Athena for deeper queries.
    • Create metric filters and alarms for:
      • REJECT records on unexpected ports or from unknown CIDRs,
      • sudden spikes in rejected packets, indicating a possible scan or DDoS attempt.
  2. Track configuration drift with AWS Config
    • Turn on the VPC network ACL changes recorder and enable the managed rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) that evaluates:
      • any addition, deletion, or re-ordering of NACL rules,
      • association of a subnet with the default, permissive NACL,
      • removal of the catch-all DENY ALL rule.
    • Set the rule to trigger on configuration changes so findings arrive in seconds.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket or pages on-call staff.
  3. Automate alerts and remediation
    • Use EventBridge to watch for AWS::EC2::NetworkAcl, AWS::EC2::NetworkAclEntry, and Config findings; auto-tag the change initiator and, if the edit is outside the change-control window, revert via an SSM Automation runbook.
    • Dashboard Flow-Log reject counts next to Config drift findings so teams can correlate traffic blocks with rule edits.
  4. Retention & audits
    • Keep Flow-Log and Config data for at least one year (or your compliance window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval.
    • Review the top rejected CIDRs and ports quarterly; tighten NACL and security-group rules accordingly.

With Flow Logs catching real-time traffic anomalies and AWS Config flagging every rule change, you gain full situational awareness over your NACLsessential for incident response, compliance, and continuous hardening.

References

  • VPC Flow Logs capture information about IP traffic going to and from network interfaces
  • AWS Config managed rules for network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Implement explicit allow lists and deny all by default
countermeasure.desc:
For every custom network ACL:

  1. start with zero trust create the ACL empty, then immediately add rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress (protocol = ALL, CIDR = 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0). This guarantees any traffic you forget to allow is automatically blocked.
  2. add explicit allows top-down insert low-numbered rules (100, 110, 120 ) only for the exact source CIDRs, ports, and protocols your workload needs (e.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR or TCP 5432 from the app tier). Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound rule so return traffic is permitted; leave everything else to the final DENY.
  3. separate by subnet assign a dedicated ACL to each subnet class (public, private-app, private-db) so an overly permissive rule in one tier cant spill into another.
  4. automate enforcement in CloudFormation/Terraform, embed the explicit allow list and the deny-all footer; add CI checks that fail if any rule references 0.0.0.0/0 outside ports you approved or if the mandatory DENY ALL rule is missing.
  5. monitor for drift enable AWS Config rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) to alert when someone adds a wildcard allow or deletes the deny footer; stream findings to Security Hub.
  6. review quarterly export VPC Flow Logs, examine top ACCEPT and REJECT sources/ports, and prune unused allows to keep the list tight.

By explicitly listing whats permitted and blocking everything else, you create a predictable, auditable perimeter that backs up your security-group strategy and limits attacker movement if an instance is compromised.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Mirror inbound and outbound rules and validate traffic flows
countermeasure.desc:
A network ACL is statelessreturn packets must be allowed explicitly. For every custom NACL you create:

  1. Mirror every allow rule
    • When you add an ingress rule (for example, rule 100 allow TCP 443 from the ALB CIDR), immediately create the matching egress rule with the same protocol, port range, and destination CIDR (rule 100 outbound ALB CIDR).
    • Keep rule numbers identical (100 in / 100 out) or use a consistent offset so reviews spot mismatches quickly.
  2. Keep denies symmetrical
    • If you explicitly deny a source CIDR or port inbound, add the same deny outbound; end both directions with rule 32766 DENY ALL.
  3. Automate mirroring in IaC
    • In CloudFormation/Terraform modules, generate the outbound rule automatically when an inbound rule is declared.
    • Add CI checks (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fail a deployment if an inbound rule has no mirror or vice-versa.
  4. Validate with Reachability Analyzer
    • After each deployment, run Reachability Analyzer between the source and destination ENIs to confirm the return path succeeds. Incorporate the check into the pipeline for continuous assurance.
  5. Monitor with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (version 3) on the subnet; create CloudWatch metric filters for REJECT packets that should have been allowed. Spikes usually mean a missing or mismatched outbound rule.
  6. Review quarterly
    • Export the NACL to a spreadsheet or IaC diff; verify every inbound rule number exists in outbound rules.
    • Review Flow-Log rejects and prune obsolete rules or add new mirrors as services evolve.

Mirrored allow/deny entries keep bidirectional traffic predictable and stop silent failures caused by asymmetric filtering.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and stateless behavior
  • VPC Reachability Analyzer validate network paths

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall and enforce IMDSv2 instance metadata options
countermeasure.desc:
Even with tight NACL rules, instances can leak data over DNS or be taken over with stolen instance-metadata tokens. Add two guardrails to every subnet that uses a custom NACL:

  1. Inspect and filter DNS with Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
    • Create a DNS Firewall rule group that:
      • Blocks known C2 / malware domains by subscribing to AWS or third-party threat-intel domain lists.
      • Allows only your corporate zones (corp.internal, *.company.com) and required AWS service domains (*.amazonaws.com).
      • Default action: BLOCK for anything not explicitly allowed (deny-list + allow-list pattern).
    • Associate the rule group with each VPC in inbound and outbound direction so lookups that bypass your forwarders are still inspected.
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver query logging; alarm when queries are blockedoften an early exfiltration signal.
  2. Require IMDSv2 (and lock it down)
    • In every launch template / Auto Scaling group, set
      • Metadata version = IMDSv2
      • HttpTokens = required
      • HttpPutResponseHopLimit = 1 (prevents lateral IMDS access).
    • Use an SCP or IAM deny policy:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:RunInstances",
         "Resource": "arn:aws:ec2:*:*:instance/*",
         "Condition": { "StringEquals": { "ec2:MetadataHttpTokens": "optional" } }
        }
    • Deploy AWS Config rules required-imdsv2 and route53-resolver-firewall-enabled (custom) so any non-compliant subnet or instance is flagged in seconds.
  3. Validate & monitor
    • Test DNS blocking by querying a sink-hole domain from an instance; it should be blocked and logged.
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs; alert if traffic is headed to the IMDS IP (169.254.169.254) from any address other than the instance itselfan indicator of credential-stealing malware.

Combining a DNS firewall with mandatory IMDSv2 closes two common gaps NACLs cant covermalicious domain resolution and metadata-service abusegiving you layered, defense-in-depth protection.

References

  • Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
  • Require and use IMDSv2 for EC2 instances

countermeasure.name: Use rule numbering best practices and conduct regular reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Keep every network ACL maintainable and predictable by adopting a consistent rule-number scheme and reviewing the list at fixed intervals:

  1. reserve number blocks by purpose
    • 100199 essential ingress (e.g., 100 allow TCP 443 from ALB CIDR, 110 allow TCP 22 from bastion).
    • 200299 matching egress for the same flows.
    • 900909 temporary change-window rules.
    • 32766 catch-all DENY ALL (last rule, both directions).
      Using gaps of 1020 between entries lets you insert new rules later without renumbering the entire ACL.
  2. mirror directions immediately
    • Create an outbound rule with the same number (or a fixed offset like +100) as each inbound allow so audits quickly spot asymmetries.
  3. document inline
    • Add a short description to every rule ("Allow 443 from ALB pl-1234") so intent remains clear months later.
  4. automate quarterly reviews
    • Export the ACL via aws ec2 describe-network-acls and check for:
      • duplicate or overlapping rule numbers,
      • unused temporary ranges,
      • missing DENY ALL footer.
    • Compare the export to VPC Flow Logs; remove allows with zero hits over the review window.
  5. build guardrails
    • Add CI/CD linting that fails if two rules share a number, if gaps < 5 exist, or if rule 32766 is not a deny.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags any NACL where the highest rule number is < 32766 (denote a missing footer) or where temporary-range entries linger past their expiry tag.

Logical numbering plus scheduled clean-ups keeps NACLs short, readable, and free of stale or shadow rulesreducing error risk and audit effort.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and best practices
  • Logging with VPC Flow Logs to validate NACL effectiveness

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Stateless behavior causing asymmetric traffic flows
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Because Network ACLs are stateless, each direction of traffic requires its own allow rule. If inbound and outbound rules arent symmetrically configured, legitimate flows can be dropped or malicious flows can sneak through one direction.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, automated provisioning scripts, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Defining inbound rules (e.g. allow TCP 443) without corresponding outbound rules.
    • Misordering NACL entries so return traffic is denied.
    • Crafting packets that exploit one-way allow rules to bypass security controls.

Impacts

  • Service Disruption: Clients can establish connections but never receive responses (or vice versa), effectively causing application-level DoS.
  • Security Evasion: Attackers send malicious payloads in one direction and have responses routed out through a different path, evading monitoring.
  • Troubleshooting Complexity: Asymmetric drops are hard to trace, increasing MTTR and operational overhead.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Inbound Permit, No Return: A web servers subnet NACL allows inbound HTTPS (TCP 443) but lacks the matching outbound rule. Clients requests succeed, but responses are dropped, making the site appear down.
  2. One-Way SSH Access: An admin opens port 22 inbound but neglects the outbound rule. Automated configuration management tools repeatedly fail health checks, draining resources.
  3. Evasion via Alternative Path: An attacker sends command-and-control traffic inbound on an allowed port. The compromised hosts replies are routed through a different subnet whose NACL permits outbound on that port, bypassing inspection.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Overly permissive rules allowing unauthorized traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive NACL rulessuch as wide CIDR allows (0.0.0.0/0) or broad port rangesenable unauthorized traffic to enter or exit your subnets, undermining intended network segmentation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, negligent administrators
  • Attack Vectors:
    • NACL entries permitting all IPs on sensitive ports (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0 on TCP 22 or 3389)
    • Allow rules for large port ranges (e.g., 102465535) rather than specific ports
    • Failure to deny-by-default by omitting restrictive deny rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers connect directly to critical services (SSH, RDP, databases)
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets unchecked
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances pivot across subnet boundaries
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of network-segmentation mandates

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open SSH Port: A NACL allows inbound TCP 22 from 0.0.0.0/0; an attacker brute-forces SSH into a bastion host.
  2. Wide Ephemeral Range: A rule permits all ephemeral ports; malware exfiltrates data by opening a random high-port outbound connection.
  3. Missing Deny Rule: Without explicit deny entries, an attacker sends malformed HTTP requests across subnets, bypassing intended firewall controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unfiltered DNS and IMDS traffic via default NACL
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Default NACLs allow all traffic, including DNS (UDP/TCP 53) and Instance Metadata Service (IMDS) requests (TCP 80 on link-local 169.254.169.254). Without filtering, attackers can abuse DNS to exfiltrate data and harvest metadata for credential theft.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised EC2 instances, automated malware
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Sending DNS queries with data-encoded payloads to external resolvers via UDP 53
    • IMDS SSRF or direct metadata calls from compromised workloads to retrieve IAM tokens
    • Lateral DNS poisoning exploiting unfiltered traffic to redirect name resolution

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data tunneled out via DNS requests
  • Credential Theft: Stolen IAM role tokens from IMDS enable privilege escalation
  • Network Reconnaissance: Attackers map internal services using unfettered DNS
  • Compliance Breaches: Unmonitored metadata access violates least-privilege practices

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. DNS Tunneling: Malware encodes stolen PII into subdomain queries (e.g. secret.data.evil.com) over UDP 53, exfiltrating data undetected.
  2. IMDS Token Harvest: A compromised container issues HTTP GETs to 169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/, grabs its role credentials, and uses them to call AWS APIs.
  3. Poisoned Resolution: An attacker injects malicious DNS responses via unfiltered UDP 53, redirecting ECS service discovery to rogue endpoints.

threat.name: Default NACL associations exposing subnets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When subnets remain associated with the default NACLwhich by default allows all inbound and outbound trafficyour network segmentation is effectively disabled, exposing every subnet to unrestricted traffic.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning VPC CIDR blocks to discover open hosts
    • Exploiting open ports on application or management interfaces
    • Pivoting through one subnet into others due to uniform allow rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services intended to be private become reachable
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets without barriers
  • Lateral Movement: Compromise of one instance leads quickly to others
  • Compliance Violations: Network-segmentation and least-privilege controls are voided

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SSH Probe & Breach: An attacker scans default-NACL subnets, finds SSH on a private bastion host, and brute-forces credentials.
  2. Intra-VPC Pivot: Malware on one EC2 instance communicates freely with database servers in another subnet, exfiltrating data.
  3. Service Discovery: Automated tooling enumerates open application ports (e.g. RDP, HTTP) across all subnets, exploiting a vulnerable web service that should have been isolated.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring of NACL activity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without VPC Flow Logs or other network-level monitoring of your NACLs, all allowed and denied packet flows occur in silence. You lose visibility into who is connecting to which subnets, when traffic is blocked, or whether anomalous patterns (scans, exfiltration attempts) are occurring.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning your network, compromised EC2 instances, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Port-scans or brute-force attempts over ports that should be denied by NACLs.
    • Data exfiltration via covert channels (DNS tunneling, HTTP over high ports) through NACL-allowed rules.
    • Lateral-movement probes where attackers pivot by sending traffic between subnets.

Impacts

  • Undetected Intrusions: Malicious connection attempts and scanning go unnoticed.
  • Data Exfiltration: Stealthy tunnels arent visible, so sensitive data can leave your VPC.
  • Delayed Response: Security teams lack the forensic data to identify and block abuse.
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to log network controls violates audit requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, SOC 2).

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealth Scan: An attacker sweeps your VPC CIDR for open ports. NACLs block many attempts, but without logs you never see the pattern.
  2. DNS Tunneling Exfiltration: Malware on an EC2 crafts DNS requests embedding stolen DB credentials. The NACL permits UDP 53, and without Flow Logs the exfil goes unnoticed.
  3. Lateral Pivot: A compromised container sends probing requests to internal API endpoints in another subnet. NACL denies them, but absent logging you cant trace or block the source.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Rule misordering leading to unintended traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Since NACLs evaluate rules in order, a misordered entry (e.g., a broad allow placed before a specific deny) can permit traffic that was meant to be blocked, or block traffic that should be allowedundermining your intended network controls.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, flawed automation scripts, and rushed emergency changes.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting a broad allow rule (e.g. 0.0.0.0/0 on all ports) above a deny for a sensitive service.
    • Deploying IaC templates that dont preserve rule sequence.
    • Manually adding rules out of sequence during incident response.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services meant to be isolated become reachable from unintended sources.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate traffic may be blocked if a deny is placed before an allow.
  • Security Gaps: Critical protections are bypassed, exposing infrastructure to attack.
  • Operational Confusion: Troubleshooting is harder when rule order, rather than rule content, is at fault.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Early Allow Wins: An admin adds an allow for TCP 5432 (PostgreSQL) from anywhere at rule 10, but the intended deny for 0.0.0.0/0 on the DB subnet is at rule 100so the database is exposed.
  2. Blocked Health Checks: A deny for ephemeral ports is placed before an allow for your monitoring systems IP range, preventing health checks from reaching your instances.
  3. IaC Drift: A Terraform update recreates the NACL and applies rules in alphabetical order, placing a broad allow above specific denies and inadvertently opening SSH to the Internet.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-477
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-477: Use of Obsolete Function The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Associate custom NACLs to subnets with strict rule sets
countermeasure.desc:
Replace the default, permissive network ACL with a custom NACL for each subnet and populate it with explicit allow rules for only the ports, protocols, and CIDRs your workload actually needs. Everything else is implicitly denied.

Implementation steps

  1. Create a dedicated NACL per subnet rather than sharing one across the VPC. This limits blast radius and simplifies audits.
  2. Build the rule set top-down
    • Low rule numbers (100, 110) for required inbound portse.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR, or TCP 5432 from the app subnet.
    • Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound allow for the ephemeral port range (1024-65535) so return traffic succeeds.
    • End with rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress to block any traffic you forgot to list.
  3. Avoid state exposure by blocking dangerous protocols and port ranges you never use (UDP 0-1023, TCP 23, 3389, etc.).
  4. Automate association in CloudFormation/Terraform:
    1. SubnetNACLAssociation:
       Type: AWS::EC2::SubnetNetworkAclAssociation
       Properties:
         SubnetId: !Ref PrivateSubnetA
         NetworkAclId: !Ref PrivateNACL
  5. Validate & monitor
    • Turn on VPC Flow Logs for the subnet; alarm on REJECT counts or unexpected source IPs.
    • Use Reachability Analyzer after every deployment to confirm intended paths still work.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags subnets using the default NACL or any NACL without a DENY-ALL rule.
    • Review rule sets quarterly; remove obsolete ports and tighten CIDRs.

Strict, subnet-specific NACLs provide a stateless firewall layer that backs up your security-group strategy and blocks accidental or malicious traffic at the VPC edge.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs and AWS config rules for NACL changes
countermeasure.desc:
Add continuous, two-layer visibility to every network ACL (NACL) so you can see what traffic is blocked or allowed and who modified the rule set:

  1. Stream data-plane traffic with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (format version 3) on every subnet that the NACL protects as well as on its individual ENIs.
    • Deliver logs to CloudWatch Logs (90-day retention) or S3 + Athena for deeper queries.
    • Create metric filters and alarms for:
      • REJECT records on unexpected ports or from unknown CIDRs,
      • sudden spikes in rejected packets, indicating a possible scan or DDoS attempt.
  2. Track configuration drift with AWS Config
    • Turn on the VPC network ACL changes recorder and enable the managed rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) that evaluates:
      • any addition, deletion, or re-ordering of NACL rules,
      • association of a subnet with the default, permissive NACL,
      • removal of the catch-all DENY ALL rule.
    • Set the rule to trigger on configuration changes so findings arrive in seconds.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket or pages on-call staff.
  3. Automate alerts and remediation
    • Use EventBridge to watch for AWS::EC2::NetworkAcl, AWS::EC2::NetworkAclEntry, and Config findings; auto-tag the change initiator and, if the edit is outside the change-control window, revert via an SSM Automation runbook.
    • Dashboard Flow-Log reject counts next to Config drift findings so teams can correlate traffic blocks with rule edits.
  4. Retention & audits
    • Keep Flow-Log and Config data for at least one year (or your compliance window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval.
    • Review the top rejected CIDRs and ports quarterly; tighten NACL and security-group rules accordingly.

With Flow Logs catching real-time traffic anomalies and AWS Config flagging every rule change, you gain full situational awareness over your NACLsessential for incident response, compliance, and continuous hardening.

References

  • VPC Flow Logs capture information about IP traffic going to and from network interfaces
  • AWS Config managed rules for network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Implement explicit allow lists and deny all by default
countermeasure.desc:
For every custom network ACL:

  1. start with zero trust create the ACL empty, then immediately add rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress (protocol = ALL, CIDR = 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0). This guarantees any traffic you forget to allow is automatically blocked.
  2. add explicit allows top-down insert low-numbered rules (100, 110, 120 ) only for the exact source CIDRs, ports, and protocols your workload needs (e.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR or TCP 5432 from the app tier). Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound rule so return traffic is permitted; leave everything else to the final DENY.
  3. separate by subnet assign a dedicated ACL to each subnet class (public, private-app, private-db) so an overly permissive rule in one tier cant spill into another.
  4. automate enforcement in CloudFormation/Terraform, embed the explicit allow list and the deny-all footer; add CI checks that fail if any rule references 0.0.0.0/0 outside ports you approved or if the mandatory DENY ALL rule is missing.
  5. monitor for drift enable AWS Config rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) to alert when someone adds a wildcard allow or deletes the deny footer; stream findings to Security Hub.
  6. review quarterly export VPC Flow Logs, examine top ACCEPT and REJECT sources/ports, and prune unused allows to keep the list tight.

By explicitly listing whats permitted and blocking everything else, you create a predictable, auditable perimeter that backs up your security-group strategy and limits attacker movement if an instance is compromised.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Mirror inbound and outbound rules and validate traffic flows
countermeasure.desc:
A network ACL is statelessreturn packets must be allowed explicitly. For every custom NACL you create:

  1. Mirror every allow rule
    • When you add an ingress rule (for example, rule 100 allow TCP 443 from the ALB CIDR), immediately create the matching egress rule with the same protocol, port range, and destination CIDR (rule 100 outbound ALB CIDR).
    • Keep rule numbers identical (100 in / 100 out) or use a consistent offset so reviews spot mismatches quickly.
  2. Keep denies symmetrical
    • If you explicitly deny a source CIDR or port inbound, add the same deny outbound; end both directions with rule 32766 DENY ALL.
  3. Automate mirroring in IaC
    • In CloudFormation/Terraform modules, generate the outbound rule automatically when an inbound rule is declared.
    • Add CI checks (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fail a deployment if an inbound rule has no mirror or vice-versa.
  4. Validate with Reachability Analyzer
    • After each deployment, run Reachability Analyzer between the source and destination ENIs to confirm the return path succeeds. Incorporate the check into the pipeline for continuous assurance.
  5. Monitor with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (version 3) on the subnet; create CloudWatch metric filters for REJECT packets that should have been allowed. Spikes usually mean a missing or mismatched outbound rule.
  6. Review quarterly
    • Export the NACL to a spreadsheet or IaC diff; verify every inbound rule number exists in outbound rules.
    • Review Flow-Log rejects and prune obsolete rules or add new mirrors as services evolve.

Mirrored allow/deny entries keep bidirectional traffic predictable and stop silent failures caused by asymmetric filtering.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and stateless behavior
  • VPC Reachability Analyzer validate network paths

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall and enforce IMDSv2 instance metadata options
countermeasure.desc:
Even with tight NACL rules, instances can leak data over DNS or be taken over with stolen instance-metadata tokens. Add two guardrails to every subnet that uses a custom NACL:

  1. Inspect and filter DNS with Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
    • Create a DNS Firewall rule group that:
      • Blocks known C2 / malware domains by subscribing to AWS or third-party threat-intel domain lists.
      • Allows only your corporate zones (corp.internal, *.company.com) and required AWS service domains (*.amazonaws.com).
      • Default action: BLOCK for anything not explicitly allowed (deny-list + allow-list pattern).
    • Associate the rule group with each VPC in inbound and outbound direction so lookups that bypass your forwarders are still inspected.
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver query logging; alarm when queries are blockedoften an early exfiltration signal.
  2. Require IMDSv2 (and lock it down)
    • In every launch template / Auto Scaling group, set
      • Metadata version = IMDSv2
      • HttpTokens = required
      • HttpPutResponseHopLimit = 1 (prevents lateral IMDS access).
    • Use an SCP or IAM deny policy:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:RunInstances",
         "Resource": "arn:aws:ec2:*:*:instance/*",
         "Condition": { "StringEquals": { "ec2:MetadataHttpTokens": "optional" } }
        }
    • Deploy AWS Config rules required-imdsv2 and route53-resolver-firewall-enabled (custom) so any non-compliant subnet or instance is flagged in seconds.
  3. Validate & monitor
    • Test DNS blocking by querying a sink-hole domain from an instance; it should be blocked and logged.
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs; alert if traffic is headed to the IMDS IP (169.254.169.254) from any address other than the instance itselfan indicator of credential-stealing malware.

Combining a DNS firewall with mandatory IMDSv2 closes two common gaps NACLs cant covermalicious domain resolution and metadata-service abusegiving you layered, defense-in-depth protection.

References

  • Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
  • Require and use IMDSv2 for EC2 instances

countermeasure.name: Use rule numbering best practices and conduct regular reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Keep every network ACL maintainable and predictable by adopting a consistent rule-number scheme and reviewing the list at fixed intervals:

  1. reserve number blocks by purpose
    • 100199 essential ingress (e.g., 100 allow TCP 443 from ALB CIDR, 110 allow TCP 22 from bastion).
    • 200299 matching egress for the same flows.
    • 900909 temporary change-window rules.
    • 32766 catch-all DENY ALL (last rule, both directions).
      Using gaps of 1020 between entries lets you insert new rules later without renumbering the entire ACL.
  2. mirror directions immediately
    • Create an outbound rule with the same number (or a fixed offset like +100) as each inbound allow so audits quickly spot asymmetries.
  3. document inline
    • Add a short description to every rule ("Allow 443 from ALB pl-1234") so intent remains clear months later.
  4. automate quarterly reviews
    • Export the ACL via aws ec2 describe-network-acls and check for:
      • duplicate or overlapping rule numbers,
      • unused temporary ranges,
      • missing DENY ALL footer.
    • Compare the export to VPC Flow Logs; remove allows with zero hits over the review window.
  5. build guardrails
    • Add CI/CD linting that fails if two rules share a number, if gaps < 5 exist, or if rule 32766 is not a deny.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags any NACL where the highest rule number is < 32766 (denote a missing footer) or where temporary-range entries linger past their expiry tag.

Logical numbering plus scheduled clean-ups keeps NACLs short, readable, and free of stale or shadow rulesreducing error risk and audit effort.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and best practices
  • Logging with VPC Flow Logs to validate NACL effectiveness

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Stateless behavior causing asymmetric traffic flows
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Because Network ACLs are stateless, each direction of traffic requires its own allow rule. If inbound and outbound rules arent symmetrically configured, legitimate flows can be dropped or malicious flows can sneak through one direction.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, automated provisioning scripts, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Defining inbound rules (e.g. allow TCP 443) without corresponding outbound rules.
    • Misordering NACL entries so return traffic is denied.
    • Crafting packets that exploit one-way allow rules to bypass security controls.

Impacts

  • Service Disruption: Clients can establish connections but never receive responses (or vice versa), effectively causing application-level DoS.
  • Security Evasion: Attackers send malicious payloads in one direction and have responses routed out through a different path, evading monitoring.
  • Troubleshooting Complexity: Asymmetric drops are hard to trace, increasing MTTR and operational overhead.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Inbound Permit, No Return: A web servers subnet NACL allows inbound HTTPS (TCP 443) but lacks the matching outbound rule. Clients requests succeed, but responses are dropped, making the site appear down.
  2. One-Way SSH Access: An admin opens port 22 inbound but neglects the outbound rule. Automated configuration management tools repeatedly fail health checks, draining resources.
  3. Evasion via Alternative Path: An attacker sends command-and-control traffic inbound on an allowed port. The compromised hosts replies are routed through a different subnet whose NACL permits outbound on that port, bypassing inspection.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Overly permissive rules allowing unauthorized traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive NACL rulessuch as wide CIDR allows (0.0.0.0/0) or broad port rangesenable unauthorized traffic to enter or exit your subnets, undermining intended network segmentation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, negligent administrators
  • Attack Vectors:
    • NACL entries permitting all IPs on sensitive ports (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0 on TCP 22 or 3389)
    • Allow rules for large port ranges (e.g., 102465535) rather than specific ports
    • Failure to deny-by-default by omitting restrictive deny rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers connect directly to critical services (SSH, RDP, databases)
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets unchecked
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances pivot across subnet boundaries
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of network-segmentation mandates

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open SSH Port: A NACL allows inbound TCP 22 from 0.0.0.0/0; an attacker brute-forces SSH into a bastion host.
  2. Wide Ephemeral Range: A rule permits all ephemeral ports; malware exfiltrates data by opening a random high-port outbound connection.
  3. Missing Deny Rule: Without explicit deny entries, an attacker sends malformed HTTP requests across subnets, bypassing intended firewall controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unfiltered DNS and IMDS traffic via default NACL
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Default NACLs allow all traffic, including DNS (UDP/TCP 53) and Instance Metadata Service (IMDS) requests (TCP 80 on link-local 169.254.169.254). Without filtering, attackers can abuse DNS to exfiltrate data and harvest metadata for credential theft.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised EC2 instances, automated malware
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Sending DNS queries with data-encoded payloads to external resolvers via UDP 53
    • IMDS SSRF or direct metadata calls from compromised workloads to retrieve IAM tokens
    • Lateral DNS poisoning exploiting unfiltered traffic to redirect name resolution

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data tunneled out via DNS requests
  • Credential Theft: Stolen IAM role tokens from IMDS enable privilege escalation
  • Network Reconnaissance: Attackers map internal services using unfettered DNS
  • Compliance Breaches: Unmonitored metadata access violates least-privilege practices

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. DNS Tunneling: Malware encodes stolen PII into subdomain queries (e.g. secret.data.evil.com) over UDP 53, exfiltrating data undetected.
  2. IMDS Token Harvest: A compromised container issues HTTP GETs to 169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/, grabs its role credentials, and uses them to call AWS APIs.
  3. Poisoned Resolution: An attacker injects malicious DNS responses via unfiltered UDP 53, redirecting ECS service discovery to rogue endpoints.

threat.name: Default NACL associations exposing subnets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When subnets remain associated with the default NACLwhich by default allows all inbound and outbound trafficyour network segmentation is effectively disabled, exposing every subnet to unrestricted traffic.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning VPC CIDR blocks to discover open hosts
    • Exploiting open ports on application or management interfaces
    • Pivoting through one subnet into others due to uniform allow rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services intended to be private become reachable
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets without barriers
  • Lateral Movement: Compromise of one instance leads quickly to others
  • Compliance Violations: Network-segmentation and least-privilege controls are voided

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SSH Probe & Breach: An attacker scans default-NACL subnets, finds SSH on a private bastion host, and brute-forces credentials.
  2. Intra-VPC Pivot: Malware on one EC2 instance communicates freely with database servers in another subnet, exfiltrating data.
  3. Service Discovery: Automated tooling enumerates open application ports (e.g. RDP, HTTP) across all subnets, exploiting a vulnerable web service that should have been isolated.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring of NACL activity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without VPC Flow Logs or other network-level monitoring of your NACLs, all allowed and denied packet flows occur in silence. You lose visibility into who is connecting to which subnets, when traffic is blocked, or whether anomalous patterns (scans, exfiltration attempts) are occurring.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning your network, compromised EC2 instances, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Port-scans or brute-force attempts over ports that should be denied by NACLs.
    • Data exfiltration via covert channels (DNS tunneling, HTTP over high ports) through NACL-allowed rules.
    • Lateral-movement probes where attackers pivot by sending traffic between subnets.

Impacts

  • Undetected Intrusions: Malicious connection attempts and scanning go unnoticed.
  • Data Exfiltration: Stealthy tunnels arent visible, so sensitive data can leave your VPC.
  • Delayed Response: Security teams lack the forensic data to identify and block abuse.
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to log network controls violates audit requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, SOC 2).

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealth Scan: An attacker sweeps your VPC CIDR for open ports. NACLs block many attempts, but without logs you never see the pattern.
  2. DNS Tunneling Exfiltration: Malware on an EC2 crafts DNS requests embedding stolen DB credentials. The NACL permits UDP 53, and without Flow Logs the exfil goes unnoticed.
  3. Lateral Pivot: A compromised container sends probing requests to internal API endpoints in another subnet. NACL denies them, but absent logging you cant trace or block the source.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Rule misordering leading to unintended traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Since NACLs evaluate rules in order, a misordered entry (e.g., a broad allow placed before a specific deny) can permit traffic that was meant to be blocked, or block traffic that should be allowedundermining your intended network controls.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, flawed automation scripts, and rushed emergency changes.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting a broad allow rule (e.g. 0.0.0.0/0 on all ports) above a deny for a sensitive service.
    • Deploying IaC templates that dont preserve rule sequence.
    • Manually adding rules out of sequence during incident response.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services meant to be isolated become reachable from unintended sources.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate traffic may be blocked if a deny is placed before an allow.
  • Security Gaps: Critical protections are bypassed, exposing infrastructure to attack.
  • Operational Confusion: Troubleshooting is harder when rule order, rather than rule content, is at fault.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Early Allow Wins: An admin adds an allow for TCP 5432 (PostgreSQL) from anywhere at rule 10, but the intended deny for 0.0.0.0/0 on the DB subnet is at rule 100so the database is exposed.
  2. Blocked Health Checks: A deny for ephemeral ports is placed before an allow for your monitoring systems IP range, preventing health checks from reaching your instances.
  3. IaC Drift: A Terraform update recreates the NACL and applies rules in alphabetical order, placing a broad allow above specific denies and inadvertently opening SSH to the Internet.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1563 - Remote Service Session Hijacking

component.name: HTTP Flood
component.desc: HTTP Flood protection rules.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-602
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-602: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server. When the server relies on protection mechanisms placed on the client side, an attacker can modify the client-side behavior to bypass the protection mechanisms, resulting in potentially unexpected interactions between the client and server. The consequences will vary, depending on what the mechanisms are trying to protect.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IAM principals to create and modify security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Create and enforce IAM policies (and, at the organization level, SCPs) so that only designated network-engineering and deployment roles can call the following APIs:

  • ec2:CreateSecurityGroup
  • ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:ModifySecurityGroupRules and ec2:DeleteSecurityGroup

Implementation guidance

  1. Define an allow-list role
    • Attach a custom policy that permits the APIs above only in required Regions and accounts.
    • Add an IAM permission boundary that blocks wildcard actions/resources, and include an approval workflow (change-management tag or AWS SSO assignment) before the role can be assumed.
  2. Deny everyone else
    • Apply a Service Control Policy at the OU or root level:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:*SecurityGroup*",
         "Resource": "*",
         "Condition": {
           "StringNotEquals": {
             "aws:PrincipalArn": [
               "arn:aws:iam::111122223333:role/NetEng-SG-Admin",
               "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/Infra-Pipeline"
             ]
           }
         }
        }
  3. Monitor and alert
    • Enable CloudTrail and an EventBridge rule that notifies security when any principal outside the allow-list role invokes a security-group API.
    • Use AWS Config rule ec2-security-group-changes to capture unauthorized edits and mark them NON_COMPLIANT for remediation.
  4. Enforce infrastructure-as-code
    • Require all security-group definitions to live in CloudFormation/Terraform. Block console edits by denying the actions above to human IAM users; grant them only to the CI/CD role after peer review.

References

  • IAM best practices grant least privilege
  • VPC security group rules recommended restrictions

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IP address ranges for ports such as SSH and RDP
countermeasure.desc:
Lock down administrative ports by allowing TCP 22 (SSH) and TCP 3389 (RDP) only from a short, vetted list of source CIDRstypically your corporate VPN, jump-host subnet, or specific engineer IPs.

Implementation guidance

  1. create tight security-group rules
    • For each workload that must be managed directly, add one ingress rule per trusted CIDR, e.g. 203.0.113.0/24 TCP 22 and TCP 3389.
    • Never leave a fallback rule such as 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0; if a public admin path is required, front it with an SSM Session Manager or a hardened bastion that enforces MFA.
  2. prevent drift
    • Attach an AWS Config managed rule restricted-ssh (for port 22) and a custom rule for port 3389; mark any security group that permits the port from 0.0.0.0/0 as NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag/Checkov) that fails builds when an ingress rule on 22 or 3389 references an unapproved CIDR block.
  3. monitor changes
    • Enable CloudTrail + EventBridge to alert on AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress or ModifySecurityGroupRules events involving ports 22/3389.
    • Review VPC Flow Logs for unexpected source IPs hitting those ports; alarm on first-seen IP addresses outside your allow list.
  4. rotate and review
    • Quarterly, re-validate the allow list against current office IPs and VPN ranges; remove stale entries immediately.
    • If engineers roam, require them to connect through the VPN or SSM rather than expanding CIDRs.

Strict CIDR allow-lists eliminate the most common attack vectorpublicly exposed management portswhile still permitting controlled administrative access.

References

  • VPC security group rules best practices
  • AWS Config rule: restricted-ssh

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define explicit outbound rules and avoid open port ranges
countermeasure.desc:
By default, new security groups permit all outbound traffic (0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0 on every port). Replace that rule with specific egress entries so instances, containers, and Lambda functions can reach only the destinations and ports they truly need:

  1. delete the default rule at creation time (or via IaC), remove the automatic All traffic / All ports / 0.0.0.0/0 egress line.
  2. add least-privilege allows
    • HTTPS (TCP 443) to interface VPC endpoints (com.amazonaws.<region>.*) or NAT CIDR for outbound internet access.
    • DB ports (e.g., 5432, 3306) targeting the database security-group ID, not a broad CIDR.
    • Any other required service port, scoped to a known destination CIDR or SGnever to 0.0.0.0/0.
  3. block high-risk ranges avoid wide port ranges (e.g., 0-65535, 1024-65535). If dynamic ports are unavoidable, document the reason and tag the rule (Purpose=EFS-data, Owner=NetEng).
  4. enforce with guardrails
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fails when an egress rule uses 0.0.0.0/0 or a large port span.
    • Enable AWS Config managed rule restricted-common-egress-ports (or a custom rule) to flag security groups whose egress is wide open.
  5. monitor & refine turn on VPC Flow Logs, observe outbound traffic for 30 days, then tighten or remove rules with little or no legitimate usage.

Explicit, narrow egress rules shrink your attack surface, stop malware from calling arbitrary endpoints, and satisfy zero-trust and compliance requirements.

References

  • Security group rules best practices
