customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS config rules and CloudTrail logging for security group changes
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on continuous monitoring so every creation, update, or deletion of a security group (SG) is recorded, evaluated, and alerted:

  1. CloudTrail (who changed what)
    • Configure a multi-Region trail that captures Management events and delivers them to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket.
    • Stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs; create an EventBridge rule that matches AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress, AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress, ModifySecurityGroupRules, and DeleteSecurityGroup, then notify an SNS topic (ChatOps/PagerDuty).
  2. AWS Config (is the change compliant?)
    • Enable the managed rules:
      • ec2-security-group-changes records every SG edit.
      • restricted-ssh and restricted-common-egress-ports flag ports 22/3389 or 0-65535 exposed to 0.0.0.0/0.
    • Add a custom rule that marks an SG NON_COMPLIANT if it allows any ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 on ports outside an approved list.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub; auto-create an incident ticket or trigger SSM automation to revert the change.
  3. Retention & evidence
    • Keep CloudTrail and Config logs for 1 year (or your regulatory window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval / Deep Archive.
    • Use Configs timeline view during audits to show exactly when and why each SG rule changed and who made the call.

With CloudTrail capturing who modified security groups and AWS Config judging whether the modification violates policy, you gain real-time visibility, rapid alerting, and audit-ready evidence for every network-layer change.

References

  • AWS CloudTrail user guide logging Amazon EC2 security-group events
  • AWS Config rules for security groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement network ACLs with rules similar to security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Add a stateless guardrail beneath every security group by creating a dedicated, deny-by-default network ACL (NACL) for each subnet and populating it with rules that replicate the security groups approved traffic patterns:

  1. start with explicit deny-all insert rule 32766 in both directions (ALL traffic / 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0) to block anything you forget to allow.
  2. copy essential allows for every security-group ingress or egress rule, add a matching NACL rule (same protocol, port range, and CIDR). Use low rule numbers (e.g., 100 inbound / 100 outbound) and keep gaps of 10 for future inserts.
  3. mirror directions because NACLs are stateless, add the reverse-path rule so return traffic is permitted; asymmetric paths cause silent drops.
  4. assign per-subnet associate the NACL only with the subnet that contains the protected ENIs; other tiers keep their own ACLs, preventing over-permissive crossover.
  5. validate continuously
    • run Reachability Analyzer after each deployment to confirm flows allowed by the security group arent blocked by the NACL,
    • enable VPC Flow Logs for the subnet and alarm on REJECT packets that hit expected ports.
  6. review quarterly export the NACL, compare to current security-group rules, remove obsolete allows, and verify the deny-all footer is still present.

A mirrored NACL provides a second, independent filter layer: if a security group is accidentally opened to the world, the subnets NACL still blocks unwanted traffic.

References

  • Working with network ACLs
  • Reachability Analyzer validate network paths

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Use minimal number of security groups and group by similar functions
countermeasure.desc:
Avoid sprawling, one-off security groups by assigning instances, containers, and load-balancer ENIs that serve the same purpose and expose the same ports to a single, well-named group (e.g., sg-web-public-https, sg-rds-postgres).
Benefits include simpler audits, fewer rules to maintain, and smaller chances of accidentally leaving an unused group with open ingress.

Implementation guidance

  1. design the portfolio list common traffic patterns (public web, internal API, database, batch-egress) and create one security group for each.
  2. lock the rule set add only the ports and CIDRs required for that function, then use the groups ID (not a CIDR) as the source in peer rules (SourceSecurityGroupId) to enable east-west communication.
  3. enforce via IaC reference the shared group IDs in CloudFormation/Terraform modules; deny ad-hoc group creation with an Organizations SCP limiting ec2:CreateSecurityGroup to network-engineering roles.
  4. track usage enable AWS Config rule unused-security-groups to flag groups with zero ENIs; delete or merge them each quarter.
  5. name and tag consistently use a prefix like sg-<layer>-<protocol> and tag with Owner, Environment, and Purpose for quick identification.

Following this practice keeps the number of active security groups small, their intent clear, and their rules tightly managed.

References

  • VPC security group rules best practices
  • AWS Config managed rule: unused-security-groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive security group proliferation leading to management errors
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups act as virtual firewalls to control inbound and outbound traffic for resources. An excessive number of security groups can lead to configuration complexity and management errors. As the number of security groups grows, maintaining consistency and ensuring proper rule application becomes increasingly challenging. This can result in inadvertent exposure of resources, conflicting rules, and gaps in the security posture.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Administrators/Developers: Create unnecessary or duplicate security groups, leading to configuration sprawl.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of cleanup or consolidation leads to excessive security groups.
  • Human Error: Managing a large number of groups increases the risk of mistakes, such as overly permissive rules.
  • Inadequate Governance: No enforcement of security group management best practices.

Impacts:

  • Inconsistent Security Policies: Conflicting or overlapping rules weaken the security posture.
  • Access Misconfigurations: Inadvertent exposure of resources due to redundant or permissive rules.
  • Operational Overhead: Increased difficulty in auditing, maintaining, and troubleshooting security group settings.
  • Security Gaps: Unused or forgotten security groups may still allow unintended access.
  • Compliance Failures: Inefficient security group management leads to policy violations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Conflicting Rules: Multiple security groups attached to an instance have overlapping and contradictory rules, allowing unintended access.
  2. Redundant Exposure: An old, unused security group still allows inbound traffic from untrusted IP ranges, exposing services unnecessarily.
  3. Management Complexity: An administrator inadvertently allows SSH from any IP due to confusion between similarly named security groups.
  4. Policy Drift: Security groups created for temporary purposes are not removed, leading to unnecessary attack surfaces over time.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Implicit allow-all egress traffic enabling potential data exfiltration
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS Security Groups, the default configuration often allows all outbound (egress) traffic unless explicitly restricted. This implicit "allow-all" rule can enable malicious actors or compromised instances to freely transmit data to external or untrusted networks. Without restricting egress traffic, data exfiltration and unauthorized communication can go unnoticed, leading to potential data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Compromise an instance and exfiltrate data via unrestricted outbound connections.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of proper egress restrictions in security group settings.
  • Insider Threats: Legitimate users misuse outbound connectivity for unauthorized data transfers.
  • Compromised Applications: Malicious or compromised containerized services initiate outbound connections.

Impacts:

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data transferred to unauthorized destinations.
  • Command and Control (C2) Communication: Attackers maintain persistence through outbound channels.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances communicate with other cloud services or regions.
  • Reputation Damage: Leaked data or malicious activities traceable to the organization.
  • Compliance Violations: Unmonitored outbound traffic may breach data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Data Leak via Compromised Instance: An attacker gains access to an instance and transfers database backups to an external server due to unrestricted outbound traffic.
  2. Command and Control (C2) Server Connection: Malware on a compromised instance communicates with a remote attacker via egress traffic.
  3. Misconfigured Security Group: A security group configured with 0.0.0.0/0 for outbound traffic allows any instance to connect to external networks.
  4. Undetected API Abuse: An application with unrestricted egress permissions uploads user data to an untrusted cloud storage location.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Lack of defense in depth by not using network ACLs
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, Network Access Control Lists (ACLs) act as an additional layer of security that controls inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level. Relying solely on security groups without implementing network ACLs can result in a lack of defense in depth. This omission increases the risk of malicious traffic reaching instances, as security groups alone may not fully mitigate complex attack scenarios or provide sufficient traffic filtering.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit unsecured network paths to reach instances.
  • Insider Threats: Abuse internal network access due to weak ACL policies.
  • Misconfiguration: Inadequate or absent network ACLs allowing unrestricted traffic.
  • Network-based Attacks: Lack of subnet-level filtering allows scanning, lateral movement, or exploitation.

Impacts:

  • Network Intrusion: Attackers gain unauthorized access to instances through unfiltered subnets.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances are used to pivot within the VPC.
  • Inconsistent Security: Relying only on security groups may leave gaps if instances are moved between subnets.
  • Service Disruption: Unfiltered traffic can degrade performance or lead to resource exhaustion.
  • Non-Compliance: Missing ACLs may violate regulatory requirements for network segmentation and control.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Subnet Compromise: An attacker gains control of an instance in a subnet without ACL restrictions, allowing unhindered lateral movement.
  2. Open Subnet Traffic: A subnet without outbound ACL restrictions allows compromised instances to freely communicate with external C2 servers.
  3. Internal Scanning: An insider runs port scans across internal subnets due to the lack of ACLs, identifying vulnerable instances.
  4. Misconfigured ACL Rules: All traffic is implicitly allowed due to missing deny rules, negating the benefit of subnet-level filtering.

threat.name: Overly permissive ingress rules on security group
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups are used to control inbound traffic to instances and services. Overly permissive ingress rules, such as allowing traffic from any IP address (0.0.0.0/0) or allowing a broad range of ports, expose the network to unauthorized access and potential exploitation. This misconfiguration significantly increases the attack surface, enabling external attackers to probe, exploit, or compromise AWS resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit open ports to gain unauthorized access.
  • Malware/Automated Scanners: Identify and attack public-facing services with weak ingress controls.
  • Insider Threats: Abuse lax ingress rules to access restricted instances.
  • Human Error: Administrators accidentally configure overly broad IP ranges or ports.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain direct access to instances or services.
  • Data Breach: Publicly accessible databases or applications leak sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers exploit open ports to crash or overload services.
  • Resource Abuse: Unrestricted ports allow attackers to hijack instances for cryptomining.
  • Compliance Failures: Inadequate access control may violate regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. SSH Brute Force Attack: An ECS instance with port 22 open to the internet (0.0.0.0/0) is targeted by automated SSH brute force attempts.
  2. Open Database Ports: An RDS instance is configured to accept connections from any IP, exposing it to SQL injection attacks.
  3. Misconfigured Web Server: A security group allows HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443) from all IPs, making the server vulnerable to application-level attacks.
  4. Exposed Management Interface: Administrative services (e.g., Kibana or Jenkins) are accessible from public networks due to broad ingress rules.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: No logging and monitoring of security group changes
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups control inbound and outbound traffic for instances and services. Failing to log and monitor changes to security group configurations can lead to unauthorized modifications going undetected. This oversight makes it challenging to track who made changes, detect suspicious activity, or investigate security incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Modify security group rules to open unauthorized access paths.
  • Insider Threats: Employees make intentional or accidental changes without oversight.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of enabling AWS CloudTrail to track security group changes.
  • Human Error: Administrators unintentionally change rules, leading to exposure.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Changes to inbound or outbound rules can expose sensitive resources.
  • Security Breaches: Attackers can open ports or IP ranges to maintain persistent access.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of monitoring and audit logs breaches data protection regulations.
  • Incident Response Delay: Without logs, detecting and investigating unauthorized changes becomes slow and difficult.
  • Misconfiguration Persistence: Accidental changes may remain unnoticed, weakening the security posture.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Silent Configuration Change: An attacker gains temporary access and modifies security groups to allow SSH from any IP, but without logging, the change goes unnoticed.
  2. Internal Misconfiguration: An administrator accidentally broadens the allowed IP range, exposing critical services, but the absence of logs prevents quick remediation.
  3. Backdoor Establishment: An insider modifies a security group to permit traffic from a malicious IP, and the lack of monitoring delays detection.
  4. Compliance Audit Failure: During a security audit, the organization cannot provide evidence of past security group changes due to missing logs.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of security groups due to insufficient IAM controls
threat.desc:
General Description:
AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies dictate who can create, modify, or delete security groups. Insufficient IAM controls can allow unauthorized users or compromised accounts to make changes to security group rules, leading to exposure of resources, reduced security, or unauthorized access. Attackers may leverage these permissions to open access to critical services, allowing lateral movement or data exfiltration.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Exploit compromised accounts with overly permissive IAM roles.
  • Insider Threats: Employees with unnecessary or elevated permissions modify security groups.
  • Misconfiguration: Roles are granted excessive permissions without the principle of least privilege.
  • Automated Scripts: Scripts running with improper permissions unintentionally modify security groups.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Open access to critical infrastructure due to modified ingress/egress rules.
  • Data Exfiltration: Attackers manipulate security groups to exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Critical services are disrupted or made inaccessible due to improper rule changes.
  • Operational Impact: Increased risk of unauthorized network access or lateral movement.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized changes compromise network security, leading to audit failures.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Privilege Escalation: An attacker compromises an IAM user account that has permissions to modify security groups. They add a rule allowing inbound SSH from any IP, gaining persistent access.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Role: A developer with broad permissions accidentally changes a security group to allow traffic from untrusted sources.
  3. Insider Tampering: An employee maliciously opens database ports to external IPs, exposing sensitive information.
  4. Automation Gone Wrong: A CI/CD pipeline script unintentionally modifies security group settings due to insufficient permission scoping, exposing internal services.

component.name: IP Reputation Lists
component.desc: IP Reputation Lists protection rules.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-477
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-477: Use of Obsolete Function The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Associate custom NACLs to subnets with strict rule sets
countermeasure.desc:
Replace the default, permissive network ACL with a custom NACL for each subnet and populate it with explicit allow rules for only the ports, protocols, and CIDRs your workload actually needs. Everything else is implicitly denied.

Implementation steps

  1. Create a dedicated NACL per subnet rather than sharing one across the VPC. This limits blast radius and simplifies audits.
  2. Build the rule set top-down
    • Low rule numbers (100, 110) for required inbound portse.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR, or TCP 5432 from the app subnet.
    • Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound allow for the ephemeral port range (1024-65535) so return traffic succeeds.
    • End with rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress to block any traffic you forgot to list.
  3. Avoid state exposure by blocking dangerous protocols and port ranges you never use (UDP 0-1023, TCP 23, 3389, etc.).
  4. Automate association in CloudFormation/Terraform:
    1. SubnetNACLAssociation:
       Type: AWS::EC2::SubnetNetworkAclAssociation
       Properties:
         SubnetId: !Ref PrivateSubnetA
         NetworkAclId: !Ref PrivateNACL
  5. Validate & monitor
    • Turn on VPC Flow Logs for the subnet; alarm on REJECT counts or unexpected source IPs.
    • Use Reachability Analyzer after every deployment to confirm intended paths still work.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags subnets using the default NACL or any NACL without a DENY-ALL rule.
    • Review rule sets quarterly; remove obsolete ports and tighten CIDRs.

Strict, subnet-specific NACLs provide a stateless firewall layer that backs up your security-group strategy and blocks accidental or malicious traffic at the VPC edge.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs and AWS config rules for NACL changes
countermeasure.desc:
Add continuous, two-layer visibility to every network ACL (NACL) so you can see what traffic is blocked or allowed and who modified the rule set:

  1. Stream data-plane traffic with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (format version 3) on every subnet that the NACL protects as well as on its individual ENIs.
    • Deliver logs to CloudWatch Logs (90-day retention) or S3 + Athena for deeper queries.
    • Create metric filters and alarms for:
      • REJECT records on unexpected ports or from unknown CIDRs,
      • sudden spikes in rejected packets, indicating a possible scan or DDoS attempt.
  2. Track configuration drift with AWS Config
    • Turn on the VPC network ACL changes recorder and enable the managed rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) that evaluates:
      • any addition, deletion, or re-ordering of NACL rules,
      • association of a subnet with the default, permissive NACL,
      • removal of the catch-all DENY ALL rule.
    • Set the rule to trigger on configuration changes so findings arrive in seconds.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket or pages on-call staff.
  3. Automate alerts and remediation
    • Use EventBridge to watch for AWS::EC2::NetworkAcl, AWS::EC2::NetworkAclEntry, and Config findings; auto-tag the change initiator and, if the edit is outside the change-control window, revert via an SSM Automation runbook.
    • Dashboard Flow-Log reject counts next to Config drift findings so teams can correlate traffic blocks with rule edits.
  4. Retention & audits
    • Keep Flow-Log and Config data for at least one year (or your compliance window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval.
    • Review the top rejected CIDRs and ports quarterly; tighten NACL and security-group rules accordingly.

With Flow Logs catching real-time traffic anomalies and AWS Config flagging every rule change, you gain full situational awareness over your NACLsessential for incident response, compliance, and continuous hardening.

References

  • VPC Flow Logs capture information about IP traffic going to and from network interfaces
  • AWS Config managed rules for network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Implement explicit allow lists and deny all by default
countermeasure.desc:
For every custom network ACL:

  1. start with zero trust create the ACL empty, then immediately add rule 32766 DENY ALL for both ingress and egress (protocol = ALL, CIDR = 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0). This guarantees any traffic you forget to allow is automatically blocked.
  2. add explicit allows top-down insert low-numbered rules (100, 110, 120 ) only for the exact source CIDRs, ports, and protocols your workload needs (e.g., TCP 443 from the ALBs CIDR or TCP 5432 from the app tier). Mirror each inbound allow with a matching outbound rule so return traffic is permitted; leave everything else to the final DENY.
  3. separate by subnet assign a dedicated ACL to each subnet class (public, private-app, private-db) so an overly permissive rule in one tier cant spill into another.
  4. automate enforcement in CloudFormation/Terraform, embed the explicit allow list and the deny-all footer; add CI checks that fail if any rule references 0.0.0.0/0 outside ports you approved or if the mandatory DENY ALL rule is missing.
  5. monitor for drift enable AWS Config rule vpc-network-acl-changes (or a custom rule) to alert when someone adds a wildcard allow or deletes the deny footer; stream findings to Security Hub.
  6. review quarterly export VPC Flow Logs, examine top ACCEPT and REJECT sources/ports, and prune unused allows to keep the list tight.

By explicitly listing whats permitted and blocking everything else, you create a predictable, auditable perimeter that backs up your security-group strategy and limits attacker movement if an instance is compromised.

References

  • Working with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Mirror inbound and outbound rules and validate traffic flows
countermeasure.desc:
A network ACL is statelessreturn packets must be allowed explicitly. For every custom NACL you create:

  1. Mirror every allow rule
    • When you add an ingress rule (for example, rule 100 allow TCP 443 from the ALB CIDR), immediately create the matching egress rule with the same protocol, port range, and destination CIDR (rule 100 outbound ALB CIDR).
    • Keep rule numbers identical (100 in / 100 out) or use a consistent offset so reviews spot mismatches quickly.
  2. Keep denies symmetrical
    • If you explicitly deny a source CIDR or port inbound, add the same deny outbound; end both directions with rule 32766 DENY ALL.
  3. Automate mirroring in IaC
    • In CloudFormation/Terraform modules, generate the outbound rule automatically when an inbound rule is declared.
    • Add CI checks (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fail a deployment if an inbound rule has no mirror or vice-versa.
  4. Validate with Reachability Analyzer
    • After each deployment, run Reachability Analyzer between the source and destination ENIs to confirm the return path succeeds. Incorporate the check into the pipeline for continuous assurance.
  5. Monitor with VPC Flow Logs
    • Enable Flow Logs (version 3) on the subnet; create CloudWatch metric filters for REJECT packets that should have been allowed. Spikes usually mean a missing or mismatched outbound rule.
  6. Review quarterly
    • Export the NACL to a spreadsheet or IaC diff; verify every inbound rule number exists in outbound rules.
    • Review Flow-Log rejects and prune obsolete rules or add new mirrors as services evolve.

Mirrored allow/deny entries keep bidirectional traffic predictable and stop silent failures caused by asymmetric filtering.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and stateless behavior
  • VPC Reachability Analyzer validate network paths

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall and enforce IMDSv2 instance metadata options
countermeasure.desc:
Even with tight NACL rules, instances can leak data over DNS or be taken over with stolen instance-metadata tokens. Add two guardrails to every subnet that uses a custom NACL:

  1. Inspect and filter DNS with Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
    • Create a DNS Firewall rule group that:
      • Blocks known C2 / malware domains by subscribing to AWS or third-party threat-intel domain lists.
      • Allows only your corporate zones (corp.internal, *.company.com) and required AWS service domains (*.amazonaws.com).
      • Default action: BLOCK for anything not explicitly allowed (deny-list + allow-list pattern).
    • Associate the rule group with each VPC in inbound and outbound direction so lookups that bypass your forwarders are still inspected.
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver query logging; alarm when queries are blockedoften an early exfiltration signal.
  2. Require IMDSv2 (and lock it down)
    • In every launch template / Auto Scaling group, set
      • Metadata version = IMDSv2
      • HttpTokens = required
      • HttpPutResponseHopLimit = 1 (prevents lateral IMDS access).
    • Use an SCP or IAM deny policy:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:RunInstances",
         "Resource": "arn:aws:ec2:*:*:instance/*",
         "Condition": { "StringEquals": { "ec2:MetadataHttpTokens": "optional" } }
        }
    • Deploy AWS Config rules required-imdsv2 and route53-resolver-firewall-enabled (custom) so any non-compliant subnet or instance is flagged in seconds.
  3. Validate & monitor
    • Test DNS blocking by querying a sink-hole domain from an instance; it should be blocked and logged.
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs; alert if traffic is headed to the IMDS IP (169.254.169.254) from any address other than the instance itselfan indicator of credential-stealing malware.

Combining a DNS firewall with mandatory IMDSv2 closes two common gaps NACLs cant covermalicious domain resolution and metadata-service abusegiving you layered, defense-in-depth protection.

References

  • Route 53 Resolver DNS Firewall
  • Require and use IMDSv2 for EC2 instances

countermeasure.name: Use rule numbering best practices and conduct regular reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Keep every network ACL maintainable and predictable by adopting a consistent rule-number scheme and reviewing the list at fixed intervals:

  1. reserve number blocks by purpose
    • 100199 essential ingress (e.g., 100 allow TCP 443 from ALB CIDR, 110 allow TCP 22 from bastion).
    • 200299 matching egress for the same flows.
    • 900909 temporary change-window rules.
    • 32766 catch-all DENY ALL (last rule, both directions).
      Using gaps of 1020 between entries lets you insert new rules later without renumbering the entire ACL.
  2. mirror directions immediately
    • Create an outbound rule with the same number (or a fixed offset like +100) as each inbound allow so audits quickly spot asymmetries.
  3. document inline
    • Add a short description to every rule ("Allow 443 from ALB pl-1234") so intent remains clear months later.
  4. automate quarterly reviews
    • Export the ACL via aws ec2 describe-network-acls and check for:
      • duplicate or overlapping rule numbers,
      • unused temporary ranges,
      • missing DENY ALL footer.
    • Compare the export to VPC Flow Logs; remove allows with zero hits over the review window.
  5. build guardrails
    • Add CI/CD linting that fails if two rules share a number, if gaps < 5 exist, or if rule 32766 is not a deny.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule that flags any NACL where the highest rule number is < 32766 (denote a missing footer) or where temporary-range entries linger past their expiry tag.

Logical numbering plus scheduled clean-ups keeps NACLs short, readable, and free of stale or shadow rulesreducing error risk and audit effort.

References

  • Working with network ACLs rule order and best practices
  • Logging with VPC Flow Logs to validate NACL effectiveness

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Stateless behavior causing asymmetric traffic flows
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Because Network ACLs are stateless, each direction of traffic requires its own allow rule. If inbound and outbound rules arent symmetrically configured, legitimate flows can be dropped or malicious flows can sneak through one direction.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, automated provisioning scripts, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Defining inbound rules (e.g. allow TCP 443) without corresponding outbound rules.
    • Misordering NACL entries so return traffic is denied.
    • Crafting packets that exploit one-way allow rules to bypass security controls.

Impacts

  • Service Disruption: Clients can establish connections but never receive responses (or vice versa), effectively causing application-level DoS.
  • Security Evasion: Attackers send malicious payloads in one direction and have responses routed out through a different path, evading monitoring.
  • Troubleshooting Complexity: Asymmetric drops are hard to trace, increasing MTTR and operational overhead.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Inbound Permit, No Return: A web servers subnet NACL allows inbound HTTPS (TCP 443) but lacks the matching outbound rule. Clients requests succeed, but responses are dropped, making the site appear down.
  2. One-Way SSH Access: An admin opens port 22 inbound but neglects the outbound rule. Automated configuration management tools repeatedly fail health checks, draining resources.
  3. Evasion via Alternative Path: An attacker sends command-and-control traffic inbound on an allowed port. The compromised hosts replies are routed through a different subnet whose NACL permits outbound on that port, bypassing inspection.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Overly permissive rules allowing unauthorized traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive NACL rulessuch as wide CIDR allows (0.0.0.0/0) or broad port rangesenable unauthorized traffic to enter or exit your subnets, undermining intended network segmentation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, negligent administrators
  • Attack Vectors:
    • NACL entries permitting all IPs on sensitive ports (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0 on TCP 22 or 3389)
    • Allow rules for large port ranges (e.g., 102465535) rather than specific ports
    • Failure to deny-by-default by omitting restrictive deny rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers connect directly to critical services (SSH, RDP, databases)
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets unchecked
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances pivot across subnet boundaries
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of network-segmentation mandates

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open SSH Port: A NACL allows inbound TCP 22 from 0.0.0.0/0; an attacker brute-forces SSH into a bastion host.
  2. Wide Ephemeral Range: A rule permits all ephemeral ports; malware exfiltrates data by opening a random high-port outbound connection.
  3. Missing Deny Rule: Without explicit deny entries, an attacker sends malformed HTTP requests across subnets, bypassing intended firewall controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unfiltered DNS and IMDS traffic via default NACL
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Default NACLs allow all traffic, including DNS (UDP/TCP 53) and Instance Metadata Service (IMDS) requests (TCP 80 on link-local 169.254.169.254). Without filtering, attackers can abuse DNS to exfiltrate data and harvest metadata for credential theft.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised EC2 instances, automated malware
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Sending DNS queries with data-encoded payloads to external resolvers via UDP 53
    • IMDS SSRF or direct metadata calls from compromised workloads to retrieve IAM tokens
    • Lateral DNS poisoning exploiting unfiltered traffic to redirect name resolution

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data tunneled out via DNS requests
  • Credential Theft: Stolen IAM role tokens from IMDS enable privilege escalation
  • Network Reconnaissance: Attackers map internal services using unfettered DNS
  • Compliance Breaches: Unmonitored metadata access violates least-privilege practices

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. DNS Tunneling: Malware encodes stolen PII into subdomain queries (e.g. secret.data.evil.com) over UDP 53, exfiltrating data undetected.
  2. IMDS Token Harvest: A compromised container issues HTTP GETs to 169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/, grabs its role credentials, and uses them to call AWS APIs.
  3. Poisoned Resolution: An attacker injects malicious DNS responses via unfiltered UDP 53, redirecting ECS service discovery to rogue endpoints.

threat.name: Default NACL associations exposing subnets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When subnets remain associated with the default NACLwhich by default allows all inbound and outbound trafficyour network segmentation is effectively disabled, exposing every subnet to unrestricted traffic.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning VPC CIDR blocks to discover open hosts
    • Exploiting open ports on application or management interfaces
    • Pivoting through one subnet into others due to uniform allow rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services intended to be private become reachable
  • Data Exfiltration & Injection: Malicious payloads traverse subnets without barriers
  • Lateral Movement: Compromise of one instance leads quickly to others
  • Compliance Violations: Network-segmentation and least-privilege controls are voided

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SSH Probe & Breach: An attacker scans default-NACL subnets, finds SSH on a private bastion host, and brute-forces credentials.
  2. Intra-VPC Pivot: Malware on one EC2 instance communicates freely with database servers in another subnet, exfiltrating data.
  3. Service Discovery: Automated tooling enumerates open application ports (e.g. RDP, HTTP) across all subnets, exploiting a vulnerable web service that should have been isolated.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring of NACL activity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without VPC Flow Logs or other network-level monitoring of your NACLs, all allowed and denied packet flows occur in silence. You lose visibility into who is connecting to which subnets, when traffic is blocked, or whether anomalous patterns (scans, exfiltration attempts) are occurring.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning your network, compromised EC2 instances, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Port-scans or brute-force attempts over ports that should be denied by NACLs.
    • Data exfiltration via covert channels (DNS tunneling, HTTP over high ports) through NACL-allowed rules.
    • Lateral-movement probes where attackers pivot by sending traffic between subnets.

Impacts

  • Undetected Intrusions: Malicious connection attempts and scanning go unnoticed.
  • Data Exfiltration: Stealthy tunnels arent visible, so sensitive data can leave your VPC.
  • Delayed Response: Security teams lack the forensic data to identify and block abuse.
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to log network controls violates audit requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, SOC 2).

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealth Scan: An attacker sweeps your VPC CIDR for open ports. NACLs block many attempts, but without logs you never see the pattern.
  2. DNS Tunneling Exfiltration: Malware on an EC2 crafts DNS requests embedding stolen DB credentials. The NACL permits UDP 53, and without Flow Logs the exfil goes unnoticed.
  3. Lateral Pivot: A compromised container sends probing requests to internal API endpoints in another subnet. NACL denies them, but absent logging you cant trace or block the source.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Rule misordering leading to unintended traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Since NACLs evaluate rules in order, a misordered entry (e.g., a broad allow placed before a specific deny) can permit traffic that was meant to be blocked, or block traffic that should be allowedundermining your intended network controls.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, flawed automation scripts, and rushed emergency changes.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting a broad allow rule (e.g. 0.0.0.0/0 on all ports) above a deny for a sensitive service.
    • Deploying IaC templates that dont preserve rule sequence.
    • Manually adding rules out of sequence during incident response.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Services meant to be isolated become reachable from unintended sources.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate traffic may be blocked if a deny is placed before an allow.
  • Security Gaps: Critical protections are bypassed, exposing infrastructure to attack.
  • Operational Confusion: Troubleshooting is harder when rule order, rather than rule content, is at fault.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Early Allow Wins: An admin adds an allow for TCP 5432 (PostgreSQL) from anywhere at rule 10, but the intended deny for 0.0.0.0/0 on the DB subnet is at rule 100so the database is exposed.
  2. Blocked Health Checks: A deny for ephemeral ports is placed before an allow for your monitoring systems IP range, preventing health checks from reaching your instances.
  3. IaC Drift: A Terraform update recreates the NACL and applies rules in alphabetical order, placing a broad allow above specific denies and inadvertently opening SSH to the Internet.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1563 - Remote Service Session Hijacking

component.name: Scanner & Probe
component.desc: Scanner and Probe protection rules.

weakness.name: CWE-1395
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1395: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Implement centralized management and monitoring in Next-Generation Firewall
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing a centralized management and monitoring system is essential for maintaining robust network security and swiftly identifying any anomalies or unauthorized activities. The following steps outline a comprehensive approach to deploying such a system effectively:

  • Select a Robust Centralized Monitoring Solution:

Choose a solution that integrates seamlessly with your Next-Generation Firewall and supports real-time monitoring. Ensure the system can handle the scale and complexity of your network infrastructure.

  • Integrate with Existing Network Infrastructure:

Ensure the monitoring system is properly integrated with all relevant network devices and security tools, including firewalls, routers, and intrusion detection systems, to provide a unified view of network activity.

  • Configure Alerts and Notifications:

Set up real-time alerts for any activities that deviate from the norm, such as unusual data transfers or attempted unauthorized access. Configure the system to notify the security team through various channels, including email, SMS, or integrated security dashboards.

  • Establish Baseline Network Behavior:

To accurately identify anomalies, develop a comprehensive baseline of typical network behavior. Use historical data and continuous learning to adjust and refine this baseline over time.

  • Implement Role-Based Access Controls (RBAC):

Incorporate RBAC within the centralized system to limit access based on user roles, ensuring that only authorized personnel have the ability to modify or interact with monitoring configurations.

  • Regularly Audit and Update System Configurations:

Conduct regular audits of the monitoring system configurations and update them as necessary to account for new security threats or changes in network topology.

  • Train Security Personnel:

Provide comprehensive training for your security personnel to ensure they are proficient in using the centralized monitoring system and can respond effectively to alerts and notifications.

  • Test and Refine the System:

Periodically test the monitoring system using simulated attacks to verify its effectiveness and refine the response protocols based on the outcomes of these tests.

By implementing a centralized management and monitoring system following these guidelines, organizations can significantly enhance their ability to detect and respond to unauthorized activities, thereby improving their overall security posture.

References

  • Top 10 Next-Generation Firewall Best Practices to Strengthen Your Organization's Security

standard.ref: SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management
SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive threat protection in Next-Generation Firewall
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively deploy a comprehensive suite of threat protection features within a Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW), follow these steps to enhance your networks defense capabilities against unauthorized access and malicious activities:

  1. Enable Intrusion Prevention System (IPS):
    • Activate the IPS feature to scan and analyze incoming traffic for malicious activities and attempts to exploit known vulnerabilities.
    • Regularly update IPS signatures to ensure the firewall can detect the latest threats.
  2. Configure Advanced Malware Protection (AMP):
    • Deploy AMP to analyze files for potential malware, utilizing configured cloud resources for comprehensive threat intelligence.
    • Set actions for detected threats, such as alerting, quarantining, or blocking files with suspicious characteristics.
  3. Establish URL Filtering:
    • Implement URL filtering to restrict access to known harmful websites or categories that could introduce security risks.
    • Customize the URL filtering policy based on organizational needs and potential threat landscapes.
  4. Activate Application Control:
    • Use application control to identify and manage applications based on bandwidth usage, potential risk, and productivity impact.
    • Create application-specific policies to permit, restrict, or block application traffic according to your organizations security posture.
  5. Apply User Identity Based Controls:
    • Leverage user identity features to enforce policies based on individual users or user groups.
    • Ensure seamless integration with the organization's directory services for effective user authentication.
  6. Implement IP Reputation and Geo-Blocking:
    • Configure IP reputation to identify and block traffic from known malicious IP addresses.
    • Utilize geo-blocking to prevent access from regions with which your organization does not have business requirements.
  7. Regularly Review and Optimize Policies:
    • Conduct regular audits of firewall policies and logs to identify and address potential weaknesses.
    • Optimize policies based on new threats, changes in network infrastructure, and evolving organizational needs.

By systematically deploying and fine-tuning these feature sets, the Next-Generation Firewall can effectively serve as a robust barrier against unauthorized access, safeguarding your network infrastructure from a wide range of potential threats.

References

  • Top 10 Next-Generation Firewall Best Practices to Strengthen Your Organization's Security

countermeasure.name: Implement granular application control in Next-Generation Firewall
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively minimize the attack surface and restrict unwanted application behaviors using a Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW), it is essential to configure granular application control settings. Follow this step-by-step guidance to implement the control:

  1. Identify Critical Applications: Begin by cataloging all applications critical to your business operations, along with their necessary functions. This will help in distinguishing between legitimate and potentially harmful applications.
  2. Enable Application Visibility: Ensure that the NGFW is configured to gather detailed information about applications in use across your network. This typically involves activating the application awareness feature on the NGFW.
  3. Define Application Control Policies: Based on the identified critical applications, create application control policies. These policies should specify which applications are allowed, restricted, or blocked entirely. Employ conditions such as user roles, time of access, or network zones to fine-tune the policies.
  4. Utilize Predefined Signatures and Categories: Make use of the NGFW's database of predefined application signatures and categories. This helps in quickly applying policies to well-known applications and streamlines the policy creation process.
  5. Implement Custom Application Definitions: For in-house or uncommon applications, consider creating custom application definitions. This ensures that they are accurately identified and managed according to your security policies.
  6. Appraise Application Dependencies and Updates: Review application dependencies to ensure that necessary services and functionalities are not inadvertently blocked. Also, keep abreast of updates from software vendors as application signatures may change over time.
  7. Monitor and Analyze Traffic: Continuously monitor application traffic patterns and behaviors. Use the NGFW's reporting and logging capabilities to analyze this data, which will inform policy adjustments and improve security posture.
  8. Regularly Review and Update Policies: As new applications and threats emerge, regularly revisit and refine application control policies. Ensure that all changes to the firewall configurations align with organizational security requirements and compliance standards.

Implementing these steps in configuring granular application control settings will significantly enhance the security of your network by reducing vulnerabilities and ensuring that only authorized, secure applications are in use.

countermeasure.name: Implement role based access control in Next-Generation Firewall
countermeasure.desc:
Countermeasure Description

To strengthen security and manage access effectively on a Next-Generation Firewall, it is crucial to implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). This countermeasure ensures that only authorized personnel can modify firewall configurations and management settings, reducing the risk of unauthorized changes and potential security breaches.

Steps to Implement RBAC

  1. Identify Roles: Start by defining clear roles within your organization that determine varying levels of access to the firewall. Examples include Firewall Administrator, Network Engineer, and Security Auditor. Each role should have distinct responsibilities and permissions.
  2. Define Permissions: For each identified role, specify the exact permissions required. This includes access to adjust configurations, run diagnostics, monitor traffic, or perform audits. Permissions should align with the principle of least privilege, providing only the access necessary for the roles functions.
  3. Configure Role-Based Access: In the firewall management console, set up the roles and assign the defined permissions. Most modern firewall systems offer built-in support for RBAC, making configuration straightforward. Ensure that roles are carefully mapped to users or groups based on their operational requirements.
  4. Assign Users to Roles: Assign your personnel to the appropriate roles based on their job functions and responsibilities. Use organizational directory services, if available, to automate role assignments and user management.
  5. Monitor and Audit Access: Implement logging and monitoring to track access activities and verify compliance with access policies. Regular audits should be conducted to review role assignments and ensure that the access rights are appropriate and up-to-date.
  6. Review and Update Roles: Periodically review and update the roles and permissions as organizational needs and security policies evolve. This includes modifying roles as necessary when job functions change or new technologies are integrated.

By establishing RBAC, organizations can ensure that firewall management is restricted to competent personnel, which thereby minimizes the risk of intrusion or configuration errors and helps maintain a robust security posture.

References

  • Top 10 Next-Generation Firewall Best Practices to Strengthen Your Organization's Security

countermeasure.name: Keep Next-Generation Firewall up-to-date
countermeasure.desc:
Keeping the Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) updated is essential to maintaining robust security. Regular updates ensure that the firewall is equipped with the latest security patches and performance enhancements. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure effectively:

  • Establish an Update Schedule:

Develop and maintain a schedule for regular updates. Determine the frequency of updates based on vendor recommendations and organizational risk assessments. Common practice suggests monthly checks for updates.

  • Stay Informed:

Regularly monitor vendor announcements and security bulletins. Subscribing to alerts from the firewall vendor can help receive timely information about available updates and critical patches.

  • Plan for Downtime:

Schedule updates during low-traffic periods to minimize impact on network performance. Inform relevant stakeholders about the planned maintenance window and expected downtime, if any.

  • Backup Configuration:

Before applying updates, perform a backup of the current firewall configuration. This allows for restoration to a previous state if an update causes issues.

  • Test Updates:

If possible, test updates in a controlled environment to evaluate their effect and ensure compatibility with existing configurations and policies.

  • Deploy Updates:

Apply updates following the manufacturers guidelines. Ensure that all components, including firmware and software modules, are addressed during the update process.

  • Verify and Monitor Post-Update:

After completing the update, verify that the firewall is functioning as expected by reviewing logs and testing key functionalities. Monitor network performance and security alerts closely in the immediate aftermath of updates.

  • Document the Process:

Maintain accurate records of all updates, including dates, versions, and any issues encountered. This documentation will be valuable for troubleshooting and future audits.

By consistently applying these practices, you can ensure that your Next-Generation Firewall remains an effective defense mechanism against emerging threats.

References

  • Top 10 Next-Generation Firewall Best Practices to Strengthen Your Organization's Security

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers aim to identify and exploit vulnerabilities within the broad attack surface of a Next-Generation Firewall to bypass its security measures.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals may utilize various tactics such as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, using social engineering to gain access, or launching DDoS attacks to overwhelm the system.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, disruption of services, and a significant compromise of network security.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may identify a weak point in the firewall's configuration or exploit a known vulnerability to gain unauthorized access to restricted network areas, allowing them to extract sensitive information or introduce malicious software. Another scenario could involve launching a DDoS attack to divert attention and resources, allowing a simultaneous stealth attack to succeed unnoticed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the control of the environment
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized entities gaining access to the control plane can manipulate configurations and policies within the Next-Generation Firewall environment, leading to potential security breaches and system compromise.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in the control plane interfaces, use phishing techniques to obtain administrative credentials, or leverage insider threats to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
This could result in altered firewall rules that permit unauthorized traffic, disable essential security functionalities, exfiltration of sensitive data, and an overall reduction in the effectiveness of network defenses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could use social engineering to obtain legitimate administrative access to the firewall control plane, allowing them to modify security settings to create holes in the defense perimeter. Alternatively, exploiting a software vulnerability could provide direct access to the control plane, enabling full manipulation of the firewall environment.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to unauthorized data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may exploit weaknesses in the Next-Generation Firewall to gain illicit access to sensitive information and unauthorized data located within the target network's environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors leveraging known or zero-day vulnerabilities in the firewall software through various network attack strategies such as crafting specific network packets.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breach, loss of confidential information, damage to organizational reputation, and possible regulatory compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an unpatched vulnerability in the firewall software and exploits it to gain access to a company's internal database, extract customer data, and sell it on underground forums. Another scenario is where the attacker uses intermediary nodes to obscure their location, making it difficult to trace the attack back to its origin.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system and are not detected
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized users gain access to the system undetected, enabling prolonged malicious operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors exploit system vulnerabilities or utilize stolen credentials to infiltrate undetected.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, operational disruption, and potentially severe financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in the firewall's software, bypasses security controls, and maintains unauthorized access for data exfiltration. Another scenario involves a cyber intruder using stolen credentials to log into the system, altering configurations without raising alerts.

countermeasure.name: Anonymize sensitive data in datasets
countermeasure.desc:
Anonymizing data is a crucial step in protecting sensitive information and minimizing the risk of exposing personal data within datasets analyzed by Amazon Athena. By implementing data anonymization, you ensure that personal data is obscured or de-identified, reducing the potential for unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively anonymize data in Amazon Athena, follow these guidelines:

  1. Understand Data Sensitivity and Compliance Requirements: Identify the types of sensitive data within your datasets and understand the compliance requirements that apply to your organization. This will help you determine the appropriate level of anonymization needed.
  2. Leverage AWS Lake Formation for Data Governance: Utilize AWS Lake Formation to manage and enforce fine-grained access controls on your datasets. Lake Formation allows you to create and enforce policies that help protect sensitive data. More details can be found in the Anonymize and manage data in your data lake with Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation blog post.
  3. Use Built-in Anonymization Functions: Amazon Athena provides built-in functions to help with data anonymization, such as masking, tokenization, and encryption. For instance, you can use SQL expressions to replace certain data fields with anonymized values. Refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation to learn more about the available functions and how to use them securely.
  4. Implement Field-Level Encryption: Use field-level encryption to encrypt sensitive fields within your datasets. This ensures that even if unauthorized access occurs, the sensitive data remains protected. AWS KMS (Key Management Service) can be used to manage cryptographic keys securely.
  5. Regularly Audit and Monitor Data Access: Conduct regular audits and monitor access to your data. AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config can help you track and log access to your Amazon Athena queries and underlying data stores, providing visibility into user actions and potential security issues.

By following these steps and leveraging the capabilities of Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation, you can effectively anonymize your data, thereby enhancing the security and privacy of the information analyzed within your data lake.

For further reference, consult the official Amazon Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of Athena table data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data stored in Amazon S3 buckets used by AWS Athena is protected from unauthorized access, configuring encryption at rest is paramount. This involves enabling server-side encryption (SSE) for the relevant S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the S3 Management Console in your AWS account.
  2. Select the bucket where Athena stores its data.
  3. Go to the "Properties" tab of the selected bucket.
  4. Locate the "Default encryption" section and click on "Edit."
  5. Choose your preferred encryption method:
    • SSE-S3: Server-Side Encryption with Amazon S3-Managed Keys.
    • SSE-KMS: Server-Side Encryption with AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Keys.
    • SSE-C: Server-Side Encryption with Customer-Provided Keys.
  6. Click "Save changes" to enable or update the encryption settings.

Enabling server-side encryption helps you comply with security standards and protects your sensitive data from unauthorized access. For more detailed instructions, refer to the official AWS documentation on encrypting data in Athena and the overarching security guidelines for Amazon S3 buckets available here.

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Lake Formation to enforce strict access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing and enforcing detailed access control policies using AWS Lake Formation can significantly enhance the security posture of your data lake environment. AWS Lake Formation provides fine-grained access controls over data stored in Amazon S3, enabling you to restrict access to datasets by granting permissions at the database, table, column, or row level. This ensures only authorized users can access specific datasets, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized data access.

To begin, ensure that AWS Lake Formation is set up and integrated with your existing AWS Athena environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Configure AWS Lake Formation: First, navigate to the AWS Lake Formation console. Here, register your Amazon S3 data lake storage resources by specifying the Amazon S3 locations where your data resides. Refer to the AWS Lake Formation Getting Started Guide for detailed instructions.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Use Lake Formation permissions to grant database, table, and column-level access to specific IAM users or roles. For instance, a policy might restrict access to a table containing sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) to only specific roles. Detailed instructions on defining these policies can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Data Access Control documentation.
  3. Integrate with AWS Athena: Ensure that your AWS Athena queries are compliant with the access controls set in Lake Formation. When users run queries in Athena, Lake Formation credentials automatically enforce the defined permissions, thus controlling access to the datasets. Review the AWS Athena and Lake Formation Integration Guide for implementation details.
  4. Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor and audit access to your datasets using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lake Formation's audit capabilities. This helps in tracking user activities and ensuring compliance with your organization's security policies. For more details, refer to the Athena CloudTrail Logs documentation and the Lake Formation Auditing documentation.

By leveraging AWS Lake Formation to implement and enforce detailed access control policies, you effectively reduce the risk of unauthorized data access in your Amazon Athena queries, thereby strengthening your overall data security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Secure query result sets
countermeasure.desc:
Storing Query Results in Encrypted S3 Buckets and Restricting Access Using IAM and S3 Bucket Policies

A key measure to secure your AWS Athena query results involves storing them in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets and ensuring that access to these buckets is strictly controlled using IAM and S3 bucket policies. Follow the steps below to implement this control effectively:

Step 1: Create an Encrypted S3 Bucket

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the Amazon S3 service.
  3. Create a new S3 bucket, or select an existing one where you want to store the query results.
  4. Ensure that server-side encryption (SSE) is enabled for the bucket. You can use either SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 2: Set Up IAM Policies

IAM policies are essential to control which users and roles have permissions to access the S3 bucket and perform actions on it. Follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Define a policy that grants necessary permissions to access the specified S3 bucket. You can utilize managed polices or create a custom policy. An example policy could be:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name", "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*"]
        }
    ]
}

Attach this policy to the respective IAM roles that need access.

Step 3: Configure S3 Bucket Policies

S3 bucket policies can be used to enforce security controls on a specific bucket. Steps to configure S3 bucket policies:

  1. Select the S3 bucket created in step 1.
  2. Go to the 'Permissions' tab.
  3. Add a bucket policy that restricts access based on IAM roles, specific IP ranges, or conditions, ensuring fine-grained control over who accesses your bucket. A sample policy might look like this:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {"AWS": "arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/RoleName"},
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "IpAddress": {"aws:SourceIp": "your-ip-range"}
            }
        }
    ]
}

By following these procedures, you ensure that your Athena query results are stored securely and that access to these results is tightly controlled. For more detailed information, please refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Use CalledVia context keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Athena service, it is crucial to limit requests to AWS Athena by configuring policies to include the aws:CalledVia global condition context key. This ensures requests are made only from authorized services.

Begin by identifying the services that are authorized to make requests to AWS Athena. These could be AWS Lambda functions, AWS Glue, or other AWS services in your environment.

Next, modify the IAM policies associated with your Athena-related roles to include the aws:CalledVia condition. This condition context key allows you to specify the services that are permitted to invoke Athena actions.

Heres a step-by-step guide to implement this:

  1. Identify the IAM roles and policies that need to be updated.
  2. Open the IAM Management Console.
  3. Navigate to the relevant policy you wish to update.
  4. Edit the policy to include the Condition block with the aws:CalledVia context key. 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": "athena:*",
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:CalledVia": [
          "lambda.amazonaws.com",
          "glue.amazonaws.com"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
  5. Apply and save the updated policy.

By including the aws:CalledVia condition context key, you significantly reduce the surface area for unauthorized access to Athena. This control ensures that only requests from specified AWS services, such as Lambda or Glue, are allowed to interact with Athena.

For further details and guidance, please refer to the official AWS Athena security documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Improper result set access
threat.desc:
General threat description
If result sets of Athena queries are not properly secured, they could be accessed by unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel gaining access to improperly secured Athena query result sets through misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, potential compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured AWS permissions to access confidential data stored in Athena query results, exposing sensitive information to unauthorized entities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without strict access controls, unauthorized users might gain access to sensitive data, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external hackers exploiting loose access permissions, and users accidentally sharing access credentials.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive data, financial repercussions, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider with knowledge of the system gains unauthorized access to financial records. An external hacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to access proprietary business information. A user accidentally shares their access credentials with a phishing attacker, compromising customer data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through intermediary services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized or intermediary services interacting with AWS Athena can lead to data leaks or malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, insiders, or unauthorized third-party services exploiting misconfigurations or security gaps.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, compliance violations, and potential damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Athena credentials through a compromised third-party service and executes queries to exfiltrate sensitive information. Alternatively, an insider uses intermediary services to route unauthorized requests, causing data exposure or unauthorized data modification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unencrypted table data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If data within Athena tables is not encrypted, it may be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the AWS environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and damage to organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS account and finds unencrypted Athena tables containing sensitive data, which they can exfiltrate. A malicious insider with access to Athena tables abuses their permissions to access and share sensitive information without detection.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper anonymization, sensitive data within datasets can be exposed to unauthorized individuals, leading to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and careless or untrained employees. Attack vectors range from direct access to the AWS Athena service without proper anonymization protocols to intercepting data in transit.
Impacts
Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential legal and compliance violations, loss of customer trust, and significant financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An employee queries a dataset in AWS Athena that contains unmasked Personally Identifiable Information (PII). The data is inadvertently shared or accessed by an unauthorized party, leading to a data breach.
Scenario 2: An external attacker leverages a misconfigured access control policy to retrieve sensitive data from AWS Athena, which was not properly anonymized, and uses the data for malicious purposes.
