weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-602
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-602: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server. When the server relies on protection mechanisms placed on the client side, an attacker can modify the client-side behavior to bypass the protection mechanisms, resulting in potentially unexpected interactions between the client and server. The consequences will vary, depending on what the mechanisms are trying to protect.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IAM principals to create and modify security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Create and enforce IAM policies (and, at the organization level, SCPs) so that only designated network-engineering and deployment roles can call the following APIs:

  • ec2:CreateSecurityGroup
  • ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:ModifySecurityGroupRules and ec2:DeleteSecurityGroup

Implementation guidance

  1. Define an allow-list role
    • Attach a custom policy that permits the APIs above only in required Regions and accounts.
    • Add an IAM permission boundary that blocks wildcard actions/resources, and include an approval workflow (change-management tag or AWS SSO assignment) before the role can be assumed.
  2. Deny everyone else
    • Apply a Service Control Policy at the OU or root level:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:*SecurityGroup*",
         "Resource": "*",
         "Condition": {
           "StringNotEquals": {
             "aws:PrincipalArn": [
               "arn:aws:iam::111122223333:role/NetEng-SG-Admin",
               "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/Infra-Pipeline"
             ]
           }
         }
        }
  3. Monitor and alert
    • Enable CloudTrail and an EventBridge rule that notifies security when any principal outside the allow-list role invokes a security-group API.
    • Use AWS Config rule ec2-security-group-changes to capture unauthorized edits and mark them NON_COMPLIANT for remediation.
  4. Enforce infrastructure-as-code
    • Require all security-group definitions to live in CloudFormation/Terraform. Block console edits by denying the actions above to human IAM users; grant them only to the CI/CD role after peer review.

References

  • IAM best practices grant least privilege
  • VPC security group rules recommended restrictions

standard.ref: AC-14 PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(2)
SC-2 Separation of System and User Functionality

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IP address ranges for ports such as SSH and RDP
countermeasure.desc:
Lock down administrative ports by allowing TCP 22 (SSH) and TCP 3389 (RDP) only from a short, vetted list of source CIDRstypically your corporate VPN, jump-host subnet, or specific engineer IPs.

Implementation guidance

  1. create tight security-group rules
    • For each workload that must be managed directly, add one ingress rule per trusted CIDR, e.g. 203.0.113.0/24 TCP 22 and TCP 3389.
    • Never leave a fallback rule such as 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0; if a public admin path is required, front it with an SSM Session Manager or a hardened bastion that enforces MFA.
  2. prevent drift
    • Attach an AWS Config managed rule restricted-ssh (for port 22) and a custom rule for port 3389; mark any security group that permits the port from 0.0.0.0/0 as NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag/Checkov) that fails builds when an ingress rule on 22 or 3389 references an unapproved CIDR block.
  3. monitor changes
    • Enable CloudTrail + EventBridge to alert on AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress or ModifySecurityGroupRules events involving ports 22/3389.
    • Review VPC Flow Logs for unexpected source IPs hitting those ports; alarm on first-seen IP addresses outside your allow list.
  4. rotate and review
    • Quarterly, re-validate the allow list against current office IPs and VPN ranges; remove stale entries immediately.
    • If engineers roam, require them to connect through the VPN or SSM rather than expanding CIDRs.

Strict CIDR allow-lists eliminate the most common attack vectorpublicly exposed management portswhile still permitting controlled administrative access.

References

  • VPC security group rules best practices
  • AWS Config rule: restricted-ssh

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define explicit outbound rules and avoid open port ranges
countermeasure.desc:
By default, new security groups permit all outbound traffic (0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0 on every port). Replace that rule with specific egress entries so instances, containers, and Lambda functions can reach only the destinations and ports they truly need:

  1. delete the default rule at creation time (or via IaC), remove the automatic All traffic / All ports / 0.0.0.0/0 egress line.
  2. add least-privilege allows
    • HTTPS (TCP 443) to interface VPC endpoints (com.amazonaws.<region>.*) or NAT CIDR for outbound internet access.
    • DB ports (e.g., 5432, 3306) targeting the database security-group ID, not a broad CIDR.
    • Any other required service port, scoped to a known destination CIDR or SGnever to 0.0.0.0/0.
  3. block high-risk ranges avoid wide port ranges (e.g., 0-65535, 1024-65535). If dynamic ports are unavoidable, document the reason and tag the rule (Purpose=EFS-data, Owner=NetEng).
  4. enforce with guardrails
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fails when an egress rule uses 0.0.0.0/0 or a large port span.
    • Enable AWS Config managed rule restricted-common-egress-ports (or a custom rule) to flag security groups whose egress is wide open.
  5. monitor & refine turn on VPC Flow Logs, observe outbound traffic for 30 days, then tighten or remove rules with little or no legitimate usage.

Explicit, narrow egress rules shrink your attack surface, stop malware from calling arbitrary endpoints, and satisfy zero-trust and compliance requirements.

References

  • Security group rules best practices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS config rules and CloudTrail logging for security group changes
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on continuous monitoring so every creation, update, or deletion of a security group (SG) is recorded, evaluated, and alerted:

  1. CloudTrail (who changed what)
    • Configure a multi-Region trail that captures Management events and delivers them to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket.
    • Stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs; create an EventBridge rule that matches AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress, AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress, ModifySecurityGroupRules, and DeleteSecurityGroup, then notify an SNS topic (ChatOps/PagerDuty).
  2. AWS Config (is the change compliant?)
    • Enable the managed rules:
      • ec2-security-group-changes records every SG edit.
      • restricted-ssh and restricted-common-egress-ports flag ports 22/3389 or 0-65535 exposed to 0.0.0.0/0.
    • Add a custom rule that marks an SG NON_COMPLIANT if it allows any ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 on ports outside an approved list.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub; auto-create an incident ticket or trigger SSM automation to revert the change.
  3. Retention & evidence
    • Keep CloudTrail and Config logs for 1 year (or your regulatory window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval / Deep Archive.
    • Use Configs timeline view during audits to show exactly when and why each SG rule changed and who made the call.

With CloudTrail capturing who modified security groups and AWS Config judging whether the modification violates policy, you gain real-time visibility, rapid alerting, and audit-ready evidence for every network-layer change.

References

  • AWS CloudTrail user guide logging Amazon EC2 security-group events
  • AWS Config rules for security groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement network ACLs with rules similar to security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Add a stateless guardrail beneath every security group by creating a dedicated, deny-by-default network ACL (NACL) for each subnet and populating it with rules that replicate the security groups approved traffic patterns:

  1. start with explicit deny-all insert rule 32766 in both directions (ALL traffic / 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0) to block anything you forget to allow.
  2. copy essential allows for every security-group ingress or egress rule, add a matching NACL rule (same protocol, port range, and CIDR). Use low rule numbers (e.g., 100 inbound / 100 outbound) and keep gaps of 10 for future inserts.
  3. mirror directions because NACLs are stateless, add the reverse-path rule so return traffic is permitted; asymmetric paths cause silent drops.
  4. assign per-subnet associate the NACL only with the subnet that contains the protected ENIs; other tiers keep their own ACLs, preventing over-permissive crossover.
  5. validate continuously
    • run Reachability Analyzer after each deployment to confirm flows allowed by the security group arent blocked by the NACL,
    • enable VPC Flow Logs for the subnet and alarm on REJECT packets that hit expected ports.
  6. review quarterly export the NACL, compare to current security-group rules, remove obsolete allows, and verify the deny-all footer is still present.

A mirrored NACL provides a second, independent filter layer: if a security group is accidentally opened to the world, the subnets NACL still blocks unwanted traffic.

References

  • Working with network ACLs
  • Reachability Analyzer validate network paths

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Use minimal number of security groups and group by similar functions
countermeasure.desc:
Avoid sprawling, one-off security groups by assigning instances, containers, and load-balancer ENIs that serve the same purpose and expose the same ports to a single, well-named group (e.g., sg-web-public-https, sg-rds-postgres).
Benefits include simpler audits, fewer rules to maintain, and smaller chances of accidentally leaving an unused group with open ingress.

Implementation guidance

  1. design the portfolio list common traffic patterns (public web, internal API, database, batch-egress) and create one security group for each.
  2. lock the rule set add only the ports and CIDRs required for that function, then use the groups ID (not a CIDR) as the source in peer rules (SourceSecurityGroupId) to enable east-west communication.
  3. enforce via IaC reference the shared group IDs in CloudFormation/Terraform modules; deny ad-hoc group creation with an Organizations SCP limiting ec2:CreateSecurityGroup to network-engineering roles.
  4. track usage enable AWS Config rule unused-security-groups to flag groups with zero ENIs; delete or merge them each quarter.
  5. name and tag consistently use a prefix like sg-<layer>-<protocol> and tag with Owner, Environment, and Purpose for quick identification.

Following this practice keeps the number of active security groups small, their intent clear, and their rules tightly managed.

References

  • VPC security group rules best practices
  • AWS Config managed rule: unused-security-groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive security group proliferation leading to management errors
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups act as virtual firewalls to control inbound and outbound traffic for resources. An excessive number of security groups can lead to configuration complexity and management errors. As the number of security groups grows, maintaining consistency and ensuring proper rule application becomes increasingly challenging. This can result in inadvertent exposure of resources, conflicting rules, and gaps in the security posture.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Administrators/Developers: Create unnecessary or duplicate security groups, leading to configuration sprawl.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of cleanup or consolidation leads to excessive security groups.
  • Human Error: Managing a large number of groups increases the risk of mistakes, such as overly permissive rules.
  • Inadequate Governance: No enforcement of security group management best practices.

Impacts:

  • Inconsistent Security Policies: Conflicting or overlapping rules weaken the security posture.
  • Access Misconfigurations: Inadvertent exposure of resources due to redundant or permissive rules.
  • Operational Overhead: Increased difficulty in auditing, maintaining, and troubleshooting security group settings.
  • Security Gaps: Unused or forgotten security groups may still allow unintended access.
  • Compliance Failures: Inefficient security group management leads to policy violations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Conflicting Rules: Multiple security groups attached to an instance have overlapping and contradictory rules, allowing unintended access.
  2. Redundant Exposure: An old, unused security group still allows inbound traffic from untrusted IP ranges, exposing services unnecessarily.
  3. Management Complexity: An administrator inadvertently allows SSH from any IP due to confusion between similarly named security groups.
  4. Policy Drift: Security groups created for temporary purposes are not removed, leading to unnecessary attack surfaces over time.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Implicit allow-all egress traffic enabling potential data exfiltration
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS Security Groups, the default configuration often allows all outbound (egress) traffic unless explicitly restricted. This implicit "allow-all" rule can enable malicious actors or compromised instances to freely transmit data to external or untrusted networks. Without restricting egress traffic, data exfiltration and unauthorized communication can go unnoticed, leading to potential data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Compromise an instance and exfiltrate data via unrestricted outbound connections.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of proper egress restrictions in security group settings.
  • Insider Threats: Legitimate users misuse outbound connectivity for unauthorized data transfers.
  • Compromised Applications: Malicious or compromised containerized services initiate outbound connections.

Impacts:

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data transferred to unauthorized destinations.
  • Command and Control (C2) Communication: Attackers maintain persistence through outbound channels.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances communicate with other cloud services or regions.
  • Reputation Damage: Leaked data or malicious activities traceable to the organization.
  • Compliance Violations: Unmonitored outbound traffic may breach data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Data Leak via Compromised Instance: An attacker gains access to an instance and transfers database backups to an external server due to unrestricted outbound traffic.
  2. Command and Control (C2) Server Connection: Malware on a compromised instance communicates with a remote attacker via egress traffic.
  3. Misconfigured Security Group: A security group configured with 0.0.0.0/0 for outbound traffic allows any instance to connect to external networks.
  4. Undetected API Abuse: An application with unrestricted egress permissions uploads user data to an untrusted cloud storage location.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Lack of defense in depth by not using network ACLs
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, Network Access Control Lists (ACLs) act as an additional layer of security that controls inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level. Relying solely on security groups without implementing network ACLs can result in a lack of defense in depth. This omission increases the risk of malicious traffic reaching instances, as security groups alone may not fully mitigate complex attack scenarios or provide sufficient traffic filtering.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit unsecured network paths to reach instances.
  • Insider Threats: Abuse internal network access due to weak ACL policies.
  • Misconfiguration: Inadequate or absent network ACLs allowing unrestricted traffic.
  • Network-based Attacks: Lack of subnet-level filtering allows scanning, lateral movement, or exploitation.

Impacts:

  • Network Intrusion: Attackers gain unauthorized access to instances through unfiltered subnets.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances are used to pivot within the VPC.
  • Inconsistent Security: Relying only on security groups may leave gaps if instances are moved between subnets.
  • Service Disruption: Unfiltered traffic can degrade performance or lead to resource exhaustion.
  • Non-Compliance: Missing ACLs may violate regulatory requirements for network segmentation and control.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Subnet Compromise: An attacker gains control of an instance in a subnet without ACL restrictions, allowing unhindered lateral movement.
  2. Open Subnet Traffic: A subnet without outbound ACL restrictions allows compromised instances to freely communicate with external C2 servers.
  3. Internal Scanning: An insider runs port scans across internal subnets due to the lack of ACLs, identifying vulnerable instances.
  4. Misconfigured ACL Rules: All traffic is implicitly allowed due to missing deny rules, negating the benefit of subnet-level filtering.

threat.name: Overly permissive ingress rules on security group
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups are used to control inbound traffic to instances and services. Overly permissive ingress rules, such as allowing traffic from any IP address (0.0.0.0/0) or allowing a broad range of ports, expose the network to unauthorized access and potential exploitation. This misconfiguration significantly increases the attack surface, enabling external attackers to probe, exploit, or compromise AWS resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit open ports to gain unauthorized access.
  • Malware/Automated Scanners: Identify and attack public-facing services with weak ingress controls.
  • Insider Threats: Abuse lax ingress rules to access restricted instances.
  • Human Error: Administrators accidentally configure overly broad IP ranges or ports.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain direct access to instances or services.
  • Data Breach: Publicly accessible databases or applications leak sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers exploit open ports to crash or overload services.
  • Resource Abuse: Unrestricted ports allow attackers to hijack instances for cryptomining.
  • Compliance Failures: Inadequate access control may violate regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. SSH Brute Force Attack: An ECS instance with port 22 open to the internet (0.0.0.0/0) is targeted by automated SSH brute force attempts.
  2. Open Database Ports: An RDS instance is configured to accept connections from any IP, exposing it to SQL injection attacks.
  3. Misconfigured Web Server: A security group allows HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443) from all IPs, making the server vulnerable to application-level attacks.
  4. Exposed Management Interface: Administrative services (e.g., Kibana or Jenkins) are accessible from public networks due to broad ingress rules.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: No logging and monitoring of security group changes
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS, security groups control inbound and outbound traffic for instances and services. Failing to log and monitor changes to security group configurations can lead to unauthorized modifications going undetected. This oversight makes it challenging to track who made changes, detect suspicious activity, or investigate security incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Modify security group rules to open unauthorized access paths.
  • Insider Threats: Employees make intentional or accidental changes without oversight.
  • Misconfiguration: Lack of enabling AWS CloudTrail to track security group changes.
  • Human Error: Administrators unintentionally change rules, leading to exposure.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Changes to inbound or outbound rules can expose sensitive resources.
  • Security Breaches: Attackers can open ports or IP ranges to maintain persistent access.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of monitoring and audit logs breaches data protection regulations.
  • Incident Response Delay: Without logs, detecting and investigating unauthorized changes becomes slow and difficult.
  • Misconfiguration Persistence: Accidental changes may remain unnoticed, weakening the security posture.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Silent Configuration Change: An attacker gains temporary access and modifies security groups to allow SSH from any IP, but without logging, the change goes unnoticed.
  2. Internal Misconfiguration: An administrator accidentally broadens the allowed IP range, exposing critical services, but the absence of logs prevents quick remediation.
  3. Backdoor Establishment: An insider modifies a security group to permit traffic from a malicious IP, and the lack of monitoring delays detection.
  4. Compliance Audit Failure: During a security audit, the organization cannot provide evidence of past security group changes due to missing logs.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of security groups due to insufficient IAM controls
threat.desc:
General Description:
AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies dictate who can create, modify, or delete security groups. Insufficient IAM controls can allow unauthorized users or compromised accounts to make changes to security group rules, leading to exposure of resources, reduced security, or unauthorized access. Attackers may leverage these permissions to open access to critical services, allowing lateral movement or data exfiltration.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Exploit compromised accounts with overly permissive IAM roles.
  • Insider Threats: Employees with unnecessary or elevated permissions modify security groups.
  • Misconfiguration: Roles are granted excessive permissions without the principle of least privilege.
  • Automated Scripts: Scripts running with improper permissions unintentionally modify security groups.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Open access to critical infrastructure due to modified ingress/egress rules.
  • Data Exfiltration: Attackers manipulate security groups to exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Critical services are disrupted or made inaccessible due to improper rule changes.
  • Operational Impact: Increased risk of unauthorized network access or lateral movement.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized changes compromise network security, leading to audit failures.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Privilege Escalation: An attacker compromises an IAM user account that has permissions to modify security groups. They add a rule allowing inbound SSH from any IP, gaining persistent access.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Role: A developer with broad permissions accidentally changes a security group to allow traffic from untrusted sources.
  3. Insider Tampering: An employee maliciously opens database ports to external IPs, exposing sensitive information.
  4. Automation Gone Wrong: A CI/CD pipeline script unintentionally modifies security group settings due to insufficient permission scoping, exposing internal services.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, its crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1110 - Brute Force||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1111 - Multi-Factor Authentication Interception||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1187 - Forced Authentication

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

component.name: Valid users
component.desc: Legitimate users accessing the web application.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1110 - Brute Force||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1111 - Multi-Factor Authentication Interception||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1187 - Forced Authentication

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1221 - Template Injection||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055 - Process Injection||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1659 - Content Injection||ATT&CK Mobile - T1516 - Input Injection

component.name: Web Application Resources
component.desc: Web application resources protected by AWS WAF.

component.name: XSS
component.desc: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) protection rules.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-602
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-602: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server. When the server relies on protection mechanisms placed on the client side, an attacker can modify the client-side behavior to bypass the protection mechanisms, resulting in potentially unexpected interactions between the client and server. The consequences will vary, depending on what the mechanisms are trying to protect.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IAM principals to create and modify security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Create and enforce IAM policies (and, at the organization level, SCPs) so that only designated network-engineering and deployment roles can call the following APIs:

  • ec2:CreateSecurityGroup
  • ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupIngress / ec2:RevokeSecurityGroupEgress
  • ec2:ModifySecurityGroupRules and ec2:DeleteSecurityGroup

Implementation guidance

  1. Define an allow-list role
    • Attach a custom policy that permits the APIs above only in required Regions and accounts.
    • Add an IAM permission boundary that blocks wildcard actions/resources, and include an approval workflow (change-management tag or AWS SSO assignment) before the role can be assumed.
  2. Deny everyone else
    • Apply a Service Control Policy at the OU or root level:
      • {
         "Effect": "Deny",
         "Action": "ec2:*SecurityGroup*",
         "Resource": "*",
         "Condition": {
           "StringNotEquals": {
             "aws:PrincipalArn": [
               "arn:aws:iam::111122223333:role/NetEng-SG-Admin",
               "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/Infra-Pipeline"
             ]
           }
         }
        }
  3. Monitor and alert
    • Enable CloudTrail and an EventBridge rule that notifies security when any principal outside the allow-list role invokes a security-group API.
    • Use AWS Config rule ec2-security-group-changes to capture unauthorized edits and mark them NON_COMPLIANT for remediation.
  4. Enforce infrastructure-as-code
    • Require all security-group definitions to live in CloudFormation/Terraform. Block console edits by denying the actions above to human IAM users; grant them only to the CI/CD role after peer review.

References

  • IAM best practices grant least privilege
  • VPC security group rules recommended restrictions

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Authorize only specific IP address ranges for ports such as SSH and RDP
countermeasure.desc:
Lock down administrative ports by allowing TCP 22 (SSH) and TCP 3389 (RDP) only from a short, vetted list of source CIDRstypically your corporate VPN, jump-host subnet, or specific engineer IPs.

Implementation guidance

  1. create tight security-group rules
    • For each workload that must be managed directly, add one ingress rule per trusted CIDR, e.g. 203.0.113.0/24 TCP 22 and TCP 3389.
    • Never leave a fallback rule such as 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0; if a public admin path is required, front it with an SSM Session Manager or a hardened bastion that enforces MFA.
  2. prevent drift
    • Attach an AWS Config managed rule restricted-ssh (for port 22) and a custom rule for port 3389; mark any security group that permits the port from 0.0.0.0/0 as NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag/Checkov) that fails builds when an ingress rule on 22 or 3389 references an unapproved CIDR block.
  3. monitor changes
    • Enable CloudTrail + EventBridge to alert on AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress or ModifySecurityGroupRules events involving ports 22/3389.
    • Review VPC Flow Logs for unexpected source IPs hitting those ports; alarm on first-seen IP addresses outside your allow list.
  4. rotate and review
    • Quarterly, re-validate the allow list against current office IPs and VPN ranges; remove stale entries immediately.
    • If engineers roam, require them to connect through the VPN or SSM rather than expanding CIDRs.

Strict CIDR allow-lists eliminate the most common attack vectorpublicly exposed management portswhile still permitting controlled administrative access.

References

  • VPC security group rules best practices
  • AWS Config rule: restricted-ssh

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define explicit outbound rules and avoid open port ranges
countermeasure.desc:
By default, new security groups permit all outbound traffic (0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0 on every port). Replace that rule with specific egress entries so instances, containers, and Lambda functions can reach only the destinations and ports they truly need:

  1. delete the default rule at creation time (or via IaC), remove the automatic All traffic / All ports / 0.0.0.0/0 egress line.
  2. add least-privilege allows
    • HTTPS (TCP 443) to interface VPC endpoints (com.amazonaws.<region>.*) or NAT CIDR for outbound internet access.
    • DB ports (e.g., 5432, 3306) targeting the database security-group ID, not a broad CIDR.
    • Any other required service port, scoped to a known destination CIDR or SGnever to 0.0.0.0/0.
  3. block high-risk ranges avoid wide port ranges (e.g., 0-65535, 1024-65535). If dynamic ports are unavoidable, document the reason and tag the rule (Purpose=EFS-data, Owner=NetEng).
  4. enforce with guardrails
    • Add a CI/CD linter (cfn-nag, Checkov) that fails when an egress rule uses 0.0.0.0/0 or a large port span.
    • Enable AWS Config managed rule restricted-common-egress-ports (or a custom rule) to flag security groups whose egress is wide open.
  5. monitor & refine turn on VPC Flow Logs, observe outbound traffic for 30 days, then tighten or remove rules with little or no legitimate usage.

Explicit, narrow egress rules shrink your attack surface, stop malware from calling arbitrary endpoints, and satisfy zero-trust and compliance requirements.

References

  • Security group rules best practices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS config rules and CloudTrail logging for security group changes
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on continuous monitoring so every creation, update, or deletion of a security group (SG) is recorded, evaluated, and alerted:

  1. CloudTrail (who changed what)
    • Configure a multi-Region trail that captures Management events and delivers them to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket.
    • Stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs; create an EventBridge rule that matches AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress, AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress, ModifySecurityGroupRules, and DeleteSecurityGroup, then notify an SNS topic (ChatOps/PagerDuty).
  2. AWS Config (is the change compliant?)
    • Enable the managed rules:
      • ec2-security-group-changes records every SG edit.
      • restricted-ssh and restricted-common-egress-ports flag ports 22/3389 or 0-65535 exposed to 0.0.0.0/0.
    • Add a custom rule that marks an SG NON_COMPLIANT if it allows any ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 on ports outside an approved list.
    • Send non-compliant findings to Security Hub; auto-create an incident ticket or trigger SSM automation to revert the change.
  3. Retention & evidence
    • Keep CloudTrail and Config logs for 1 year (or your regulatory window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval / Deep Archive.
    • Use Configs timeline view during audits to show exactly when and why each SG rule changed and who made the call.

With CloudTrail capturing who modified security groups and AWS Config judging whether the modification violates policy, you gain real-time visibility, rapid alerting, and audit-ready evidence for every network-layer change.

References

  • AWS CloudTrail user guide logging Amazon EC2 security-group events
  • AWS Config rules for security groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement network ACLs with rules similar to security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Add a stateless guardrail beneath every security group by creating a dedicated, deny-by-default network ACL (NACL) for each subnet and populating it with rules that replicate the security groups approved traffic patterns:

  1. start with explicit deny-all insert rule 32766 in both directions (ALL traffic / 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0) to block anything you forget to allow.
  2. copy essential allows for every security-group ingress or egress rule, add a matching NACL rule (same protocol, port range, and CIDR). Use low rule numbers (e.g., 100 inbound / 100 outbound) and keep gaps of 10 for future inserts.
  3. mirror directions because NACLs are stateless, add the reverse-path rule so return traffic is permitted; asymmetric paths cause silent drops.
  4. assign per-subnet associate the NACL only with the subnet that contains the protected ENIs; other tiers keep their own ACLs, preventing over-permissive crossover.
  5. validate continuously
    • run Reachability Analyzer after each deployment to confirm flows allowed by the security group arent blocked by the NACL,
    • enable VPC Flow Logs for the subnet and alarm on REJECT packets that hit expected ports.
  6. review quarterly export the NACL, compare to current security-group rules, remove obsolete allows, and verify the deny-all footer is still present.

A mirrored NACL provides a second, independent filter layer: if a security group is accidentally opened to the world, the subnets NACL still blocks unwanted traffic.

References

  • Working with network ACLs
  • Reachability Analyzer validate network paths
